Review Defect engineering of electrocatalysts for metal-based battery Xiaoni Liu a Xiaobin Liu a b * Caixia Li a b * Bo Yang b Lei Wang a b c * a Key Laboratory of Eco-chemical Engineering, Ministry of Education, International Science and Technology Cooperation Base of Eco-chemical Engineering and Green Manufacturing, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266042, Shandong, China Key Laboratory of Eco-chemical Engineering Ministry of Education International Science and Technology Cooperation Base of Eco-chemical Engineering and Green Manufacturing Qingdao University of Science and Technology Qingdao Shandong 266042 China Key Laboratory of Eco-chemical Engineering, Ministry of Education, International Science and Technology Cooperation Base of Eco-chemical Engineering and Green Manufacturing, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266042, Shandong, China b College of Environment and Safety Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266042, Shandong, China College of Environment and Safety Engineering Qingdao University of Science and Technology Qingdao Shandong 266042 China College of Environment and Safety Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266042, Shandong, China c College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266042, Shandong, China College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering Qingdao University of Science and Technology Qingdao Shandong 266042 China College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266042, Shandong, China * Corresponding author To conquer the instability of clean energy, developing high performance energy storage devices is of vital importance. Among them, metal-based battery (such as Metal-air batteries and metal-sulfur batteries) exhibited high potential for application due to their low lost and high energy density. The rational design of electrode materials (catalysts) plays an important role in improving the energy storage efficacy for metal based batteries and promoting the development of renewable energy technology. With the continuous development of energy storage technology and the in-depth exploration of the electrode reaction mechanism, the researchers found that the electrochemical performances of batteries can be significantly improved by modifying the electrode materials through defect engineering. The introduction of defects in the catalytic electrode material can not only adjust the electronic structure of the catalyst and enhance intrinsic activity, but also the defects can provide a large number of unsaturated sites and provide more favorable active centers for improving the electrochemical kinetics. This paper systematically reviews the action mechanism of defect engineering in the electrocatalytic process and the latest progress in energy storage developments. The reaction mechanism of metal-air batteries and metal-sulfur batteries is introduced firstly. Afterward, the types of defects (intrinsic defects, anion vacancy, cation vacancy, lattice distortion, and heteroatomic doping) and their preparation strategies are summarized. Subsequently, with the typical metal-based batteries (Zn-air battery, Li-O2 battery, Li-CO2 battery, Li-S battery, Na-S battery, etc.) as the foothold, the important role of defect engineering in its application is summarized in detail. Finally, the current challenges and development prospects of metal-based batteries are proposed, aiming to broaden the catalytic electrode materials through defect engineering and promote the commercialization process of clean energy storage devices. Graphical Abstract This review takes electrocatalysis as the starting point and battery catalysis as the foothold, and puts forward insights on the application, development and prospect of energy storage technology in the future. Keywords Defect engineering Electrocatalyst Zn-air battery Li-O2 battery Li-S battery 1 Introduction In modern society, the energy crisis and environmental pollution have accelerated the demand for green and renewable energy [1]. Recently, renewable energy sources like hydroelectric, biomass, wind, wave, tidal energy, and solar power have been exploited growingly. Nevertheless, solar power and wind energy are limited by climate and season changes [2]. Hence, there is an urgent need to find a secure, reliable, and effective method to stockpile these renewable and continuous energy sources. By far, Li-ion batteries are the most widely used energy storage devices and are diffusely applied in electronics equipment and electric vehicles [3]. However, the long-term weaknesses of high-temperature performance, insufficient energy density, high cost, and safety problems seriously restrict their large-scale application in electric vehicles. Rechargeable metal-based batteries, such as metal-air batteries and Li-S batteries, are promising candidates for electrochemical energy storage systems due to their high energy density, design tunability, low cost, and green environmental protection [4]. Taking metal-air batteries as an example, the theoretical energy densities (Fig. 1 ) of metal-air batteries are much higher than that of other types of batteries, displaying great potential in the developments for energy storage [5,6]. It exhibited that metal-air batteries have distinct potential in improving energy density. However, the research on metal-air batteries is still in its early stage, and there are some disadvantages such as low available discharge capacity, slow transport rate and unsatisfactory cycle life. The major reaction of metal-air batteries is the dissolution/deposition reaction on anodes, including the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) on cathodes [7]. The energy density of metal-air batteries is mainly based on metal electrodes, and the cathode can acquire oxygen directly from the air as active materials, which reduces the volume and mass of the cathode. Li-S batteries are regarded as one of the most likely metal-based batteries to meet future energy needs due to their very high theoretical specific energy (2600 Wh kgâ1) and volume energy (2800 Wh Lâ1), outperforming existing Li-ion batteries (Fig. 2 ). In addition to the high specific capacity, sulfur as an active cathode material is not only environmentally friendly, but also abundant in stock and cost-effective. Besides, Metal-air batteries, owing to their high theoretical specific energy (5928 Wh kgâ1) and outstanding working voltage (theoretically 2.96 V), have received wide focus. Nevertheless, Li is unstable when contacts air and aqueous electrolytes. Aluminum-air and magnesium-air batteries display higher energy densities than zinc-air batteries (ZABs). However, they exhibit low rechargeability owing to their severe self-discharge and poor coulombic efficiency [8]. Fortunately, the data indicate that the properties of Zn and Fe are more stable and can be charged faster in alkaline electrolytes. Furthermore, Zn has obtained more focus due to its high specific energy (1218 Wh kgâ1) and output voltage (1.66 V). What is more, Zn-air batteries have a lot of merits like no pollution, low expenses, high security, and are deemed to be one of the newest energy storage devices in the future. Although metal-based batteries have great potential and have been studied deeply, further developments of metal-based batteries have been restricted by corrosion of metal electrodes and low activity of catalysts. Up to now, the most successful application of primary metal-based batteries (for example ZABs) is in medical and communication [9]. Because of the low efficiency of catalysts and poor power output ability they have attracted much attention for their high energy density. Furthermore, the future of rechargeable metal-based batteries is limited by the nonuniform dissolution and deposition of the metallic anode and the lack of meeting the demand for bifunctional air catalysts. In the research of cutting-edge storage and energy conversion technologies, a comprehensive study focuses on the design of high-efficiency electrocatalysts [10â12]. Despite that a lot of research results have been made, seeking and constructing effective catalysts to polish up the function of the ORR and OER are yet imminently demanded. What is more, another momentous and utility problem is the high cost of the electrocatalysts. Platinum (Pt) has become the most extensive ORR electrocatalyst for its outstanding catalytic activity and stability, and serves as a reference electrode for the evaluation of ORR catalysts [13]. Similarly, OER is the inverse reaction of ORR, which is also complex internally due to its four-electron transversion and the dislodge of four protons from the electrolyte. When applied in different electrolyte environments, precious metal oxides, like RuO2 and IrO2, are still considered the best catalyst for OER activity, but scarcity and cost limit their large-scale applications. More importantly, when applying a high anodic potential to the electrode, RuO2 and IrO2 are readily oxidized to acid-soluble RuO4 and IrO3, so they are unstable in acids [14]. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop high-powered metal electrocatalysts with both ORR and OER activity. Crystal defects are the destruction of the perfect periodic arrangement of atoms or molecules in crystalline materials, which inevitably exist in all electrocatalytic materials [15]. For a long time, the role of structural defects in electrocatalytic materials has been misunderstood, where defects are considered unfavorable factors for the electrocatalytic process. In fact, the defective metal materials exhibited better performance than expected [16]. In recent years, researchers have improved the activity of catalysts in metal-based batteries through defect engineering. Introducing defects such as heteroatom doping, atomic vacancies, intrinsic defects, or lattice defects on the catalyst surface can effectively tune the electronic construction of the catalytic center and improve the interrelated chemisorption patterns in the gas evolution reaction, thus improving the application of metal-based batteries in real life [17]. At present, there has been a lot of related literature on the defect engineering catalyst in metal-based batteries related to some excellent work [18â20]. However, the introduction of defects in catalysts still needs to be reviewed promptly. Here, we primarily look back at the latest advance of metal-based batteries in defect engineering. 2 The electrocatalysis reaction mechanism 2.1 OER/ORR reaction mechanism The traditional metal-air battery consists of four main components: an air electrode composing a catalyst painted gas diffusion layer (GDL), a separator, an alkaline electrolyte, and a metal electrode (Fig. 3 ) [21]. Currently, the rates of ORR and OER of air electrodes are key factors limiting rechargeable metal-air batteries. There is no doubt that understanding the reaction mechanism and processes of ORR and OER is crucial for developing catalysts with excellent performance and strong environmental adaptability. In general, the ORR mechanism can essentially be either dissociation or associative, depending on the oxygen adsorption mode on the catalyst surface and the dissociation barrier [22]. There are two types of oxygen adsorption modes for ORR reactions in alkaline solution: end-on O2 adsorption (an O atom vertically coordinated with the catalyst) and bidentate O2 adsorption (two O atoms coordinated with the catalyst), which leads to the two-electron (2eâ) pathway of peroxide and the direct four-electron (4eâ) pathway, respectively [23]. The 2eâ pathways of end-on O2 adsorption are characterized by no O=O bond breaks when the O2 molecules are adsorbed. HO2 â is corrosive as the intermediate, resulting in a relatively poor ORR activity and stability [22]. The reaction equation is as follows: (1) O2 + H2O + 2eâ â HO2 â + OHâ (2) HO2 â + H2O + 2eâ â 3OHâ The 4eâ reaction process formed by the bidentate O2 adsorption differs from the 2eâ reaction process in that the O2 molecules are first dissociated into the adsorbed oxygen atoms during the reaction process, and the 4eâ pathway is more favorable and effective for making full use of oxygen [24]. Usually, the electrocatalytic ORR process is mainly controlled by the basic reaction steps of O2 reduction and *OH reduction, and the activation barrier of the *OOH and *OH intermediates directly affects the rate of the entire ORR reaction process [25]. The reaction equation is as follows (* for the active site, and *OH, *O, and *OOH for the adsorbed intermediate): (3) * + O2 + H2O + eâ â *OOH + OHâ (4) *OOH + eâ â *O + OHâ (5) *O + H2O + eâ â *OH + OHâ (6) *OH + eâ â * + OHâ The OER is the charging process of the air cathode and whose reaction path is completely opposite to the four-electron path of the ORR. In alkaline media, four OHâ are converted into one O2 molecule and two H2O molecules with four electron transfers [26]. The steps are as follows: (7) * + OHâ â *OH + eâ (8) *OH + OHâ â O* + H2O +eâ (9) *O + OHâ â *OOH + eâ (10) *OOH + OHâ â * + O2 + H2O + eâ The metal cations on the surface are considered the main active site of the OER, and the d-number of electrons in the e-orbit has a great impact on improving the activity of the OER. Furthermore, the entire OER reaction rate is limited by the activation barrier between the intermediates and the strength of the metalâO bond during the reaction [27]. Although both OER and ORR are spontaneous, electrocatalysts are still needed to accelerate the reaction process due to the slow redox reaction of oxygen during the charge/discharge cycles. Due to the different active site requirements of ORR and OER, it is difficult to show excellent ORR and OER electrochemical properties by one catalyst alone. Although two single-functional catalysts can be combined to achieve bifunctional catalysis, the combination increases the cost and difficulty of the preparation process. Fig. 3(b) is a bifunctional volcanic model constructed from the proportional relationship between the free energies of oxygen intermediates during the ORR and OER [28]. It can be seen that the binding energies of the intermediates of the most active OER and ORR catalysts are not the same, so the best OER catalysts do not provide the best ORR catalysis, and vice versa. Therefore, the development of catalysts with both excellent ORR and OER performance remains a challenging and important task. 2.2 S reaction mechanism Metal-S (M-S) battery is a typical anode candidate for metal ion batteries because the sulfur cathode can provide excellent theoretical capacity (1672 mAh gâ1) [29]. Typical M-S batteries mainly include a sulfur cathode, metal anode, organic electrolyte, and separator [30]. Sulfur chemistry is associated with the 16-electron conversion on the cathode (S8 + 16eâ â 8S2â). Sulfur always appears in the most stable cyclic octasulfide (S8) in more than 30 solid allomorphs. The typical charge/discharge curve of the Li-S batteries is shown in Fig. 4 . It can be seen that the composition and structure of S8 change during the redox process, including the phase transition of solid (S8) â liquid (S8 2â, S6 2â, S4 2â) â solid (S2 2â/S2â), and the gradual reduction of sulfur chain length [31]. The electrochemical reaction of s is as follows: (11) S8 + 2eâ + 2Li+ â Li2S8 (12) 3Li2S8 + 2eâ + 2Li+ â 4Li2S6 (13) 2Li2S6 + 2eâ + 2Li+ â 3Li2S4 (14) Li2S4 + 2eâ + 2Li+ â 2Li2S2 (15) Li2S2 + 2eâ + 2Li+ â 2Li2S The red curve represents the discharge process, and the complex process can be divided into two steps. Stage I and Stage II provide as the first step a theoretical capacity of about 418 mAh gâ1, corresponding to the conversion of sulfur to polysulfide intermediates (S8 â S6 2â â S6 2â â S4 2â). The second step consists of stage III and stage IV, providing a theoretical capacity of about 1254 mAh gâ1, representing changes in the insulating discharge product (S4 2â â S2 2â â S2â). During subsequent charging, solid-state S2 2â/S2â is reconverted to sulfur through the formation of polysulfide intermediates, leading to reversible cycling. Although an excellent specific capacity can be achieved by this ideal electrochemical conversion reaction, the dissolution and diffusion of polysulfides raise a range of problems. It is universally known that the dissolution of the polysulfide intermediate into the electrolyte causes a low discharge capacity and a rapid capacity attenuation during cycling. What's more, bulk sulfur expansion occurs by about 80% during the cycle process, which leads to electrode pulverization and structure collapse [32]. Besides, the polysulfide shuttle effect leads to low self-discharge and low coulombic efficiency during cycling. In addition, the uneven solid electrolyte interface and dendrites can subreact the electrolyte, consuming Li metal and electrolyte, resulting in poor reversibility and low coulombic efficiency during repeated plating and stripping [33]. Therefore, the specific capacity of the sulfur anode could not be actually realized in real situations. 3 Fundamentals of defects 3.1 Definition and types of defects Crystal defect is the location where the internal structural integrity of the crystal is damaged. It is shown that the arrangement of the particle deviates from the periodically repetitive space lattice law in the local range of the crystal structure. According to its degree of an extension, it is divided into four types: point defect, line defect, surface defect and body defect [35]. According to the second law of thermodynamics, there must be defects and unorganized structures in crystal materials, especially point defects, which is a defect that deviates from the normal arrangement of the crystal structure on knots or within adjacent microscopic regions [36]. Line defect refers to a defect caused by dislocation of the atomic plane in the crystal [37]. It is characterized by small dimensions in two directions, another direction extends longer, also known as a one-dimensional defect, the concentrated expression is dislocation. The surface defect is a lattice defect occurring within a range of about several atoms along both sides of a face inside or between grains [38]. It mainly includes stack faults and various interfaces within and between crystals. Body defects belong to three-dimensional defects, which mainly include the precipitation phase, the stomata in the grain and the second phase inclusions. Defective engineering of electrocatalysts is a booming field. The introduction of defects modulates the electronic and surface properties of the catalyst to enhance its intrinsic activity. However, the present results find that not all types of defects contribute to improving the properties of electrocatalytic materials. Research on line defects has been reported rarely. In 2018, Liu et al. [39] characterized the line defects in borane sheets at an atomic level. The line defects energetically favor spatially periodic self-assembly to generate new borane phases, preparing for future fundamental research. Later, Jeong et al. [40] identified a novel line defect in the strain NTO perovskite in the NTO/STO heterostructure. The authors proposed that it presents new opportunities in the field of perovskite oxides and may also be a cornerstone of grain boundaries, riveting defects, and other planar defects in perovskite [41,42]. In addition, the dislocations in the surface defects play a significant impact on the electroluminescence (EL) based displays and cathodoluminescence (CL) technologies [43,44]. The body defects are large in three dimensions and have not been reported as catalysts according to our knowledge. Point defects are widely reported in the electrocatalysis area, which can be segmented into intrinsic defects and non-intrinsic defects [45,46]. The intrinsic defect is that the particles on the lattice node do thermal motion near their equilibrium position, and the higher energy particles leave their equilibrium position, comprising the Schottky defect and Frankel defect [47,48]. In the crystal, the atoms move from the inside lattice point to the crystal surface due to the fluctuation of the thermal vibration energy, leaving a vacancy in the original lattice point position, which leads to the Schottky defect. The vacancy can be neutral, positive or negative. If the atoms separated from the lattice run to the adjacent atomic voids to form interstitial atoms, this defect is called the Frencker defect. The lattice distortion is that the appearance of defects destroys the equilibrium state between atoms. Non-intrinsic defects, called impurity defects, are the largest number of point defects. Impurity particles with smaller radius often enter the crystal with interstitial particles [49]. Impurity defects generally do not change the lattice of the original matrix crystal, but will be activated by lattice distortion, providing conditions for particle migration, which can effectively regulate the electrochemical properties of the electrode materials. Therefore, we classify the common point defects in electrocatalytic materials into four categories, namely intrinsic defects, anion/cation vacancies, lattice distortion, and heteroatom doping. 3.2 Strategies for introducing defects The introduction of defects in electrode materials can visibly change the electrochemical properties of the materials and affect the capacity and cycling stability of the batteries. Therefore, it is very important to thoroughly understand the internal mechanism of defect formation and efficaciously construct suitable defects on the surface of the electrode material [50]. There are a lot of ways to form defects, containing chemical methods and physical methods, as follows. There are many methods to form defects, as shown in Fig. 5 , which are divided into chemical/thermal reduction, exfoliation, chemical etching, plasma technology, and balling milling. 3.2.1 Thermal/chemical reduction Thermal reduction refers to the method of forming defects through high-temperature heat treatment in a special atmosphere [51]. For instance, anion vacancies are often introduced on the surface of non-layered composite materials with high-temperature reduction. Duan et al. [52] reported that under an environment of high temperature and high pressure, the oxygen vacancy concentration in the crystal is greatly increased, which significantly reduces the thermal conductivity of the material. Besides, it is a universal method to introduce oxygen vacancies into metal oxide OER electrocatalyst materials through hydrogen reduction. Ca2Mn2O5 produces highly ordered oxygen vacancies under 5% H2/Ar at 350 Â°C for 3 h [53]. In addition to thermal reduction, chemical reduction refers to the wet-chemical process with water or organic solvents at a specific temperature and pressure. For layered oxides and transition metal two-dimensional semiconductor materials, it is very simple to fabricate defects on the surface of two-dimensional materials through solvothermal ways. Moreover, the intermittent stripping of organic solvents is normally contributed to introducing defects like surface lattice deformation. For example, Co3O4 with oxygen-rich vacancies can be prepared by the thermal reduction process of a mixed solution of ammonium tungstate and sodium dodecyl sulfate treated by thermal hydrogen [54]. 3.2.2 Exfoliation Exfoliation means that the intermittent stripping of organic solvents is normally contributed to introducing defects like surface lattice deformation. Antimonen was e obtained by chemical stripping of antimony (Sb) using H2SO4, which achieved efficient large-size stripping and created a high density of active edge sites [55]. 3.2.3 Chemical etching Chemical etching means that some metal elements in electrode materials are lightly etched by strong acid or alkali to form massive vacancies. For instance, the metal-organic skeleton is treated by selenic acid-assisted etching as the precursor to achieve the carbon-coated 3D metal selenide M m Se n (Co0.85Se1âx , NiSe2âx , FeSe2âx ) with a rich Se space as a high-performance precious metal-free OER electrocatalyst [56]. The selenic acid partially etched the ZIF-67 frame, served as a source of selenium under mediated conditions, and finally obtained carbon layer coated M m Se n derivatives after moderate temperature calcination in an inert atmosphere, as shown in Fig. 6(a) . Most important of all, compared with the traditional one-step calcination methods, the current se-acid-assisted etching strategy has successfully introduced selenium-rich vacancies in the M m Se n /C hollow structure, greatly increasing the number of active sites, raising the conductivity, thus reducing the energy barrier of intermediate formation, and thus significantly improving the OER catalytic activity in strong alkaline media (Fig. 6(b)). The observations in the TEM images indicated that defect-richolk-shell nanocages with sizes of 500â600 nm formed (Fig. 6(c)). In addition, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy verified the presence of numerous selenium vacancies in the annealed samples. As shown in Fig. 6(d), the strong EPR signal at g = 2.003 is caused by trapped electrons originating from the Se vacancy. 3.2.4 Plasma technology Plasma technology is the plasma produced by strengthening the electromagnetic field of neutral gas, which acts on the surface of the electrocatalyst to produce defects. Plasma technology is widely used because of the rapid introduction of defects on the surface of materials. Especially, electrode materials are synthesized and modified at low temperature [57]. Similarly, plasma etching can improve the ORR and OER electrocatalyst properties [58]. For example, the defects in the edge position of carbon materials can be increased by argon plasma etching, which can generate more active sites for ORR and improve the ORR performance [59]. Except for the inherent defects in regulating carbon-based materials, plasma technology can introduce defects on the surface of transition metal oxides to control the physical and chemical properties of electrode materials. For example, the introduction of oxygen defects into Co3O4 nanosheets by plasma etching can significantly improve OER performance [60]. The untreated Co3O4 after argon plasma etching can clearly see the formation of oxygen defects from the results of XPS spectra. Besides, the increase of specific surface area and active sites improves the OER properties of the electrode materials. 3.2.5 Ball milling Besides, Mechanical ball milling is peeling off two-dimensional layered materials under the action of a mechanical ball, which is a high-profit and high-efficiency method for the preparation of defects [61]. Especially, compared with other materials, carbonized materials can obtain more edge defects by mechanical ball milling [62]. Liu et al. [63] prepared a ball-milling method induced defect assisted with ZnCl2 for creating defect-rich iron/nitrogen co-doped graphene-based materials (Fe-N-G). The method of the B-Zn-FeNG catalyst is prepared as shown in Fig. 7(a) . Due to the mechanical mixing of the ball-milling, urea and FeCl3 can be more evenly mixed with graphene-like materials, which favors urea molecules and FeCl3 to anchor at the defect edge. During following the pyrolysis process, the defective sites of graphene-like materials can be doped with nitrogen and iron. At the same time, the carbon matrix is constantly corroded by ZnCl2 and evaporates at high temperatures, further leading to several pores and defects. Finally, an iron/nitrogen co-doped graphene-like material with rich defects (B-Zn-Feng) was successfully prepared. The morphology of B-Zn-FeNG was surveyed by means of SEM and TEM. Small dense blocks could be seen in the SEM image of B-Zn-FeNG (Fig. 7(b)) and B-Zn-FeNG have a layered graphene-like structure (Fig. 7(c)). Besides, the sp 2/sp 3 hybridized âriver basinâ-like structure can be sighted in Fig. 7(c). This hybrid structure provided numerous active sites and had favorable electron transport ability, thus improving the catalytic performance. 4 Characterization technique Advanced characterization techniques are necessary to reveal the types and concentration of the defects in the electrocatalysts, which can help gain insight into the role of the defects on their catalytic properties. Advanced and appropriate characterization techniques are very beneficial for studying the qualitative and quantitative effects of defects in the active site and the changes in electrocatalytic reaction pathways, providing useful guidance for synthetic efficient and stable bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts. We summarize some common and effective techniques for characterizing defect engineering in electrocatalysts. 4.1 Transmission electron microscopy TEM is microscopy that uses high-energy electron beams to pass through the sample and generate a variety of information about the sample, enabling direct imaging of the material at an atomic scale [64,65]. For example, the AC-HRTEM technology can be used to directly observe the defects in various catalysts. In particular, HAADF-STEM can display images scaled proportionally to the square of the atomic numbers, which is often used to detect defects in various electrocatalysts including pure carbon defects and vacancies in metal-based catalysts. Moreover, HAADF-STEM is also effectively detected for heteroatom-modified carbon defects in graphene, oxygen defects in metal oxide, and sulfur vacancies in transit metal disulfide species. Yuan et al. [66] prepared the defective CoSACs (Co@DMOF) by a simple decarboxylation-defect induction strategy to fully improve the degree of defect, and optimize the electronic structure of the transition metal site and the adsorption energy of key intermediates. As shown in Figs. 8(a,b) , HAADF-STEM and HRTEM show that the Co@DMOF-T materials adopt pumicelike morphologies. It can be seen that abundant isolated bright dots in the onion-like carbon sheet in the Co@DMOF-900 AC HAADF-STEM image (Fig. 8(c)). Meanwhile, aberration-corrected low-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC LADDF-STEM) was applied to observe the defects in Co@DMOF-900. It is found that not only non-hexagonal carbon defects are formed in carbon skeletons, but also the Co-N4 sites are indeed defective (Fig. 8(d)). 4.2 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and photoluminescence spectroscopy XPS is a sensitive spectroscopic tool for analyzing the chemical elements and electronic states on the surface of solid materials. The electronic structure and bond energy of the material can change after introducing the defect, leading to differences in the XPS spectra [144]. PL spectroscopy is also an effective technique for detecting defects in electrocatalysts. The main principle is that defects in electrocatalysts often act as carrier composite sites during carrier transport, leading to different PL spectra. Du et al. [67] prepared a LaCoO3 perovskite (La0.8Sr0.2Co0.8Fe0.2O3âÏ , LSCFO) porous nanoparticles with oxygen vacancies as promising cell catalysts for Li-O2 battery. As shown in the Co 2p XPS measurement spectrum in Fig. 9(a) , the formation of the oxygen vacancies occurs due to the co-doping of Sr and Fe. Two electrons are left for each oxygen vacancy, which is readily seduced by adjacent site cations, resulting in reduced binding energy. Thus, the binding energy in the Co 2p spectrum is shifted slightly to the lower binding energy. The peak at 529.8 eV in the O 1s XPS test spectrum is assigned to defective oxygen (O2 2â/Oâ). Photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy further confirmed the presence of oxygen vacancies in LSCFO. In Fig. 9(c), the peak located at ~427 nm is attributed to the rebinding hole of the two electrons trapped by the oxygen vacancies. Peak intensity was positively correlated with the oxygen vacancy concentration. It can be seen that the intensity of LSCFO in Fig. 9(c) is much higher than that in LCO, LCFO, and LSCO, indicating a higher oxygen vacancy concentration in LSCFO. 4.3 Electron paramagnetic resonance EPR, also known as electron spin resonance (ESR), is an effective method for studying materials with unpaired electrons based on the Zeeman effect. When vacancy-induced suspended bonds exist in the electrocatalyst material, the EPR signal is most likely different from the vacancy-free electrocatalyst. Therefore, the technique can be used to verify whether there are defects in the electrocatalyst. Meanwhile, the EPR spectra can also be used to verify the refilling of heteroatoms into oxygen vacancies and confirm the presence of sulfur defects in metal sulfide. As shown in Fig. 10(d) , EPR spectroscopy showed that all samples exhibited EPR signals at g = 2.003, which is related to the presence of oxygen vacancies. The maximum signal intensity of LSCFO also implies that LSCFO has the highest oxygen vacancy concentration. Oxygen vacancies are considered beneficial to improve the oxygen adsorption capacity of the material. Therefore, the electron transfer path is significantly shortened due to the presence of large oxygen vacancies, which ultimately increases the exchange current density and reduces the charge/discharge overpotential of the oxygen electrode reaction on the LSCFO surface. 4.4 Positron annihilation spectroscopy The positron annihilation spectroscopy (PAS) can analyze unique information about the positron lifetime and strength (such as a highly localized state in lattice defects). In the presence of defects such as vacancies, vacancy clusters or dislocation, positrons are subsequently trapped in the bound state in such a defect, leading to a change in the positron annihilation spectrum. Thus, PAS is an outstanding technique for detecting various types of solid material defects and their corresponding concentrations. Guo et al. [68] prepared the Pt-Cu nanowire network with enriched copper vacancy defects. In Figs. 10(a,b), the HR-TEM images of VCu-PtCu clearly illustrate many lattice defects. The authors performed PAS tests to further investigate the type and concentration of vacancy defects on the catalyst surface. The PAS shows that the PtCu and VCu-PtCu catalysts are similar in their spectral shape to Fig. 10(c). From the fitting results of the PAS, more Cu vacancies were introduced in the VCu-PtCu catalyst. The simulation results in Figs. 10(d,e) demonstrate a projection of the positron density distribution of PtCu and VCu-PtCu, revealing that the VCu-PtCu catalyst has a higher concentration of vacancies. 4.5 Other analytical techniques Besides, there are some other common defect characterization techniques. Step radiation photoelectron energy spectroscopy (SRPES) is different from common X-ray sources. Synchrotron radiation-based sources with high brightness, wide energy spectrum, high photon flux, high collimated beam, and super sensitivity to nanomaterials surfaces make SRPES one of the most effective methods to study the chemical environment of defective nanomaterials. The diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectra contain similar information to the infrared absorption spectrum. However, due to the multiple absorption behavior of infrared light, the DRIFT spectra signal intensity is much stronger and favorable for the identification of intermediates and defects during catalysis. Furthermore, ICP-AES, X-ray fluorescence (XRF), and UV-visible spectra can also be used as detecting defect structures. 5 Study the catalytic performance of the essence of electrode defects It is difficult to detect the changes of intermediates in the reaction process for most of the characterization of the before and after reaction states of catalysts. However, gaining insight into the dynamic evolution of the structure during the reaction and revealing the changes of the key intermediates and the real-time identification of the active substances in the electrochemical reactions are important for us to improve the electrochemical properties. Combining DFT calculation and in situ characterization technology, studying the surface chemistry and reaction mechanism of defective electrode materials in the process of battery charging and discharging, and detecting the intermediates produced on the surface of the electrode material, is the key to our design of the next generation of catalysts. Therefore, the model is established for theoretical simulation and calculation, which explores the reaction active site, reveals the reaction mechanism, and provides solutions to the battery stability problems. 5.1 Role of DFT calculation in defective electrocatalysts In the past few decades, great progress has been made in the synthesis of electrocatalysts and the basic catalytic mechanisms of reactions [69]. However, the basic principle and the catalytic reaction mechanism of the catalyst active site are still not clear, which seriously affects the application of the catalyst in the industry. The DFT calculation based on quantum mechanics is one of the most powerful computational methods for studying the structure-activity relationship of electrocatalysts at the atomic level. Identifying the reactive active site and understanding the reaction mechanism are two key approaches to enhance electrocatalytic performance. The identification of the reactive active site can only be determined indirectly by analyzing the relationship between controllable factors and catalytic properties. Indeed, many intermediate states of the electrocatalytic reaction and electron transfer processes are extremely difficult to probe due to their ultra-short lifetimes and complex reaction conditions, which always make the active site and the corresponding catalytic mechanism ambiguous. Therefore, identifying the active sites involved in the various electrocatalytic reactions by combining the experimental characterization and DFT calculations is a relatively straightforward strategy. At the same time, deeply understanding the catalytic mechanism of electrocatalytic reactions can accelerate the screening of potential catalysts. Numerous studies have demonstrated the outstanding contribution of DFT calculation in the prediction and discovery of advanced electrocatalysts. The DFT calculation can identify the intrinsic electronic properties of the materials, helping to build a simple predictive model that screens for promising materials in a rational atomic design. Liang et al. [70] activated and optimized the rational C-vacancy to phosphorus carbide (Î²-PC) by using DFT calculation. The P-vacancies and C-vacancies are thought to be the active sites for HER catalysis. Theoretical results show that higher concentrations of C vacancies lead to larger formation energies and poor surface stability. When introducing a reasonable concentration of either P or C vacancies, a new state appears at the gap at the Fermi level. It significantly increases the conductivity and hydrogen binding strength, which favors the HER process. Furthermore, the systematic DFT calculation provides reasonable design guidance for the feasibility of the transition metal single-atom (SA) formation on a defective carbon and the ORR activity of the resulting SA [71]. Wu et al. [72] proposed a rational design using DFT calculations and ML prediction for the feasibility of forming a transition metal SA on a defective carbon surface, which reveals the intrinsic relationship between the catalytic activity of a single-atom catalyst (SAC) and the topology, bonding and electronic structure of SAC and its bonding carbon defect site. The smaller the decomposition energy barrier of metal SA to a single vacancy (SV site) attached to the carbon surface, the easier it is for metal SA to leave the host NP (Fig. 11(a) ). SA may need to diffuse for a certain distance over the carbon surface before encountering the defect site and being anchored, which are limited by the defect density on the carbon carrier surface. Fig. 11(b) shows the diffusion barrier of the different metal SA on a defect-free carbon surface, arranged in increasing order. The thermal stability of the metal SA is determined by its binding energy to the carbon surface defect site. The higher the binding energy, the more stable the thermal fluctuations of the metal SA. Fig. 11(c) shows the binding energy of metal SA to single vacancy (SV) and double vacancy (DV) sites of different transition metal species. It is clear that the binding energy of metal SA to the defective site is significantly higher than that of the defect-free carbon surface, and is higher to the DV site compared to the SV sites. In other words, the defects on the carbon surface play a key role in anchoring the metal SA, providing ideal stability of the metal SA to the temperature. The values of diffusion barrier and binding energy between SA and carbon surface defects can be used as a reference for selecting appropriate transition metal and carbon carrier. Furthermore, the DFT calculations can be used to well understand the source of the active site and to explain the electrocatalytic reaction pathway in the chemical conversion reactions. Peng et al. [73] used DFT calculation to elucidate the reasons for the enhancement of OER performance on H2Ooct-NFO NC/IF. In the OER process in alkaline media, the key catalytic process is the adsorption and transformation of intermediates, including *OH, *O, and *OOH (Fig. 12(a) ). As shown in Fig. 12(b), the lower energy barrier of HOoct-NFO in the rate determination step (RDS, *O to *OOH) indicates a higher activity of OER. To gain insight into the difference in the binding strength of *O on HOoct-NFO and NFO, the density of states (DOS) of Fe and the d-band center (the true active site of HOoct-NFO) Fe d orbits (Figs. 12(c,d)) were calculated. Compared to the NFO, more DOS was shifted down in the Fe d orbit of the HOoct-NFO, indicating a weaker binding between the *O intermediate and the HOoct-NFO. Fig. 12(e) represents the optimized structure of the intermediates on the HOoct-NFO and NFO surfaces during OER, and identifies the exposed Feoct sites in the FeO5 unit as the active sites. Thus, the modification of HOoct-NFO induces the Fe cation filling into the octahedral void, which not only constructs a large number of active Feoct sites, but also generates FeO5 sites with better catalytic activity. On the other hand, it adjusts the electronic structure to optimize the adsorption of the intermediates, thus improving the catalytic properties. It is known that defect engineering favors exposure of the active site and edge positions of typical nanomaterials. Moreover, it can control the atomic distribution and electronic structure of the materials precisely [34]. Hence, defect engineering can play a key role in enhancing the electrocatalytic effects in various electrochemical reactions. Defect engineering in M-S batteries is expected to capture polysulfide intermediates and facilitate metal sulfide nucleation and disassembly during oxidation during subsequent reduction. Therefore, defect engineering in M-S batteries can achieve fast polysulfide conversion and stable sulfur chemistry. The introduction of defects in bifunctional catalysts can largely solve the current problems existing in metal-based batteries. First of all, the introduction of defects in the transition metal oxide catalyst can lead to stronger covalent bonds and a reduced charge transfer barrier between the metal and oxygen to alter the electronic structure of the material, which may lead to higher OER or ORR catalytic properties. Secondly, the presence of defects can greatly improve the electronic conductivity of metal materials, thus enhancing the OER or ORR activity of oxides [74]. Finally, it is well known that when defects are introduced into metal materials, and the surface properties of the material are significantly altered, greatly reducing the uneven deposition of metals and dendrite production in the metal-based battery [75]. Therefore, we introduce the method for introducing defects into metal catalyst materials in this article. Moreover, the types of metal defective materials and their application in different metal-based batteries are summarized. What is more, the prospect is made for the future development and application of metal defective materials. 5.2 Role of in situ characterization techniques in defective electrocatalysts Due to the rapid development of science and technology, many advanced instruments have been developed to monitor the electrochemical behavior of electrocatalyst surfaces in situ, such as X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), Raman spectroscopy, electron microscopy, synchrotron radiation Fourier transform infrared spectra, and UV-visible spectra [76]. In this section, we focus on recent advances about in situ infrared spectroscopy, in situ Raman spectroscopy, in situ synchrotron XRD, and operator/in situ XAS for the characterization of the catalyst and the understanding of the reaction mechanism. 5.2.1 In situ IR spectroscopy Although direct evidence of the existence of defects can be provided by the HRTEM images, the reaction between defects and intermediates cannot be dynamically observed. In situ IR spectroscopy can monitor the dynamic behavior of defective catalytic active sites and the peroxide-generated intermediates generated by peroxides, effectively tracking the reaction pathway of the electrocatalysis process. Lee et al. [77] thoroughly characterized the structure of 600 Â°C annealed mildly reduced graphene oxide (mrGO-600) to clarify the origin of its catalytic activity. In situ IR spectroscopy data suggest that both catalysts can produce peroxides during ORR in Fig. 13 . More interestingly, asymmetric carbonate vibrations were observed at 1650 and 1550 cmâ1 due to the interaction between the catalytic active sites and the adsorbed reaction intermediates, which means that O2 molecules were chemically adsorbed on the defective sp 2 carbons during the ORR process. Thus, the defective sp 2 carbon at the crystal boundary between the ether group and the noncontinuous graphite region can be efficiently converted from an oxygen molecule to peroxides. 5.2.2 Operando/in-situ Raman spectroscopy and in situ synchrotron XRD Raman spectroscopy can be used to defect levels in carbon and other solid materials through defect activation peaks. Furthermore, the XRD is also a powerful tool for studying the defects of the electrocatalyst, where the doped heteroatoms can induce a lattice mismatch into the nanocrystals, leading to a small displacement of the XRD peaks [78]. However, the results are not always convincing due to are accompanied by the gradual reaction of short-lived intermediates, which is difficult to detect by non-in situ experiments. In situ technology can be used to track the evolution of sulfur substances, and explore the unique real-time catalytic activity of the defective electrocatalysts to reveal the catalytic mechanism within the defective catalyst. Operando/in situ Raman spectroscopy can provide valuable time-resolved spectral information to help monitor reaction intermediates and identify active substances during electrochemical reactions [79]. Furthermore, the in-situ synchrotron XRD has also been used to reveal the details of the transformation of sulfur material in the electrocatalysis process. Ci et al. [80] reported an in-situ Raman binding with the in-situ synchrotron XRD to explore the redox reaction mechanism of the VSe2-VG@CC deficient electrocatalyst polysulfides. As shown by the in-situ Raman analysis of the VSe2-VG@CC/S cathode in different states (Figs. 14(aâc) ), the peak at 469.0 cmâ1 corresponds to the characteristic signal of the soluble LiPS (Li2S n , 4 â¥ n â¥ 8), confirming the strong anchoring effect of VSe2-VG on the LiPS. Furthermore, small shoulder peaks of 212â214 cmâ1 correspond to Se vacancies. It can be used as an active site to capture the sulfur materials. It can be observed that a small peak, in turn, gradually disappears into the spectrum during the discharging process, and that the release of a certain amount of Se vacancies during charging process leads to the regeneration of the shoulder peak signal at 212â214 cmâ1. In situ XRD was tested to explore the sulfur redox reactions during discharging/charging at the VSe2-VG@CC/S cathode. The presence of VS2 signal and changes in Li2S signal intensity can be clearly observed throughout the discharging/charging process. Fig. 14(e) schematically illustrates the polysulfide regulation process of the VSe2-VG heterostructure. Combined with DFT calculations and operational characterization, Se vacancy can greatly enhance the capture of polysulfide for VSe2, generating VS2 in situ during electrochemical reactions, thus ensuring a strong affinity for metal selenide. 5.2.3 X-ray absorption spectrum XAS is a common technique to characterize the local electron and geometry of the catalyst and track the changes in the coordination environment, coordination number, and valence of the metal phase, which includes X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). XANES is a region generated by the excitation of core electrons to valence and conduction bands, which is usually used to detect the dynamic local changes of oxidation state/electronic structure. EXAFS is a region interacting by the scattering of the photoelectron with adjacent atoms, which is commonly used to determine the dynamic changes of local geometry and bond distance. Xiao et al. [81] constructed pure spinel Co3O4 and oxygen-enriched Co3O4 (VO-Co3O4) as catalyst models to study the defect mechanism through various operational characterization, and the dynamic behavior of defect sites in the process of OER. Fig. 15(a) is XANES recorded at the Co K-edge of cobalt-based samples, confirming the lower Co oxidation state of VO-Co3O4 caused by oxygen vacancies. The operando XAFS is to probe the potential-dependent structure and oxidation state of the surface Co sites reconstructed by a dynamic defect electrocatalytic mechanism during the g OER process. Especially at the low anode potential during the OER (Fig. 15(b)), the oxygen defects significantly impact on the oxidation of the cobalt sites. As shown in Figs. 15(c,d), the Co K-edge data (recorded at OCP to 1.75 V and RHE) were collected at the critical potential to assess the oxidation state changes of Co. The presence of oxygen vacancies promotes the adsorption of OHâ at the active Co sites to form an M-OHâ¢ intermediate, which subsequently promotes the deprotonation process at a low potential (1.45 V) to form reactive oxygen species (Co-OOHâ¢) on the surface, leading to enhanced OER activity. Fig. 15(c) shows the relative changes in the various coordination environments surrounding the crystal structure of the cobalt site during the OER process, revealing the critical role of oxygen vacancies on Co peroxidation and structural reconstruction. These results illustrate the importance of XAS in deeply exploring and understanding the dynamic surface structure-activity correlation on VO-Co3O4 during the OER process, deepening our research on the intrinsic reaction mechanism of defective electrocatalysts and the dynamic behavior of defect sites. 6 The role and design rules of the defects in electrocatalytic battery 6.1 The role of the defects in electrocatalysis Unraveling the secrets of catalytic activity is crucial for the rational design of electrocatalysts. The reaction rate of the electrocatalytic process largely depends on the intrinsic electronic structure of the electrocatalyst, which enhances the catalytic activity by changing the intermediate adsorption energy, reaction barrier and activation energy [82]. In addition, the number of active sites during the reaction and the stability of the catalyst structure also greatly affect the effect of the catalyst [83]. Defect engineering is undoubtedly the more common and efficient method to improve the performance of electrocatalysts. Therefore, the discussion of how the defects act with the electrocatalysts provides more scientific guidance for us to achieve high-efficiency electrocatalysts with high intrinsic activity, long-term stability, and the desired selectivity. Here, we discuss the role of defect engineering in electrocatalysts from three different aspects in this section, which may contribute to a better understanding of the defect effects in electrocatalysis. 6.1.1 Modulating electron density and charge distribution It is already known that the binding strength between the catalytic surface and the reaction intermediate determines the reaction rate of the catalysis, while the electronic structure and charge distribution of the transition metal surface determine the size of the binding energy [84]. According to the d-band theory during the ORR process, the upward shift of the d-band center leads to a stronger interaction with the adsorbent, while the downward shift of the d-band center leads to a weaker interaction [21]. Therefore, the introduction of defect engineering in the electrocatalyst can adjust the position of the d-band center according to the demand, changing the electronic structure, and thus regulating the catalytic activity. Moreover, the introduction of defects in the transition metal materials greatly changes the normal configuration of the electrons, leading to a preferential distribution of the electrons that can optimize the adsorption energy. The intrinsic activity of the active center can be potentially improved by optimizing the adsorption energy between the adsorbent and the catalytic surface, thus improving the electrocatalytic properties of the electrocatalyst. Fig. 16(a) shows the basic steps of the process in catalysis. As shown in Fig. 16(b), the introduction of the defects makes the type of adsorption between the reactant and the surface of the catalyst change from physical adsorption to chemical adsorption, resulting in an increase in the adsorption strength, promoting the adsorption kinetics, and thus improving the electrocatalytic properties [85]. In addition, as the reaction progresses, the defect-induced electron redistribution can also reduce the energy barrier of the RDS, which accelerates the reaction kinetics and increases the rate of the electrocatalytic process (Fig. 16(c)). In addition, the defect-induced electron distribution can change the reaction pathway against the reaction barriers of different intermediates (Fig. 16(d)), guiding us to design electrocatalysts with specific selectivity and high activity. He and colleagues prepared nickel hydroxide electrocatalysts with controlled nickel vacancies (VNi) concentrations and proved that the presence of VNi can facilitate the remodeling of nickel hydroxide electrocatalysts [86]. The presence of VNi leads to the appearance of new defect levels and an increase in the hole density near the Fermi level, which can accelerate the charge transfer to facilitate the formation of the active material. Furthermore, VNi-rich Î±-Ni(OH)2 with high defect concentrations exhibit new levels of a defect in the band gap. This implies that the presence of defects increases the carrier density, thereby improving the charge transport performance. 6.1.2 Acting as adsorption site/active site Recently, the introduction of defects into electrode materials can store more foreign ions and improve the electrochemical properties of sulfur-based batteries. The researchers found that introducing defects into the context of materials can increase the exposed active site, and defects can easily anchor foreign ions, optimizing electrochemical properties. Defects have a strong chemisorption ability to sulfur species in the M-S batteries, inhibiting the dissolution and shuttling behavior of the polysulfides. As shown in Fig. 17 , the defect site on the surface of the catalyst administers captures the polysulfide intermediates, and then promotes the formation and decomposition of the intermediates during redox processes, achieving fast polysulfide conversion kinetics [34]. Defects can not only serve as the adsorption site in the reaction process, but also promote the construction of the active sites, boosting the reaction kinetics and electrocatalytic reaction, which are also unique advantages of defect engineering. Ye et al. [87] prepared a metal-free carbon with rich dopant nitrogen and intrinsic carbon defect (N/DC) for an efficient electrocatalytic oxygen reduction. The N doping released from Zn-N x is at the edge of the vacancy, and cooperates with the intrinsic carbon defect to form the N/DC coupling site. This N/DC coupling site endows N-doped carbon materials and can facilitate the ORR process. 6.1.3 Maintaining structural stability The structural instability of materials in the electrochemical process leads to poor electrochemical properties, which has always been a difficult problem facing electrocatalysis. Recently, researchers have shown that defects in structures can achieve a high degree of structural flexibility and stability during foreign ion extraction and insertion. Liu et al. [88] prepared a superfine alloy AuPd nanowires with Boerdijk-Coxeter structures (AuPd NWs). Due to the formation of numerous crystal defects on the nanowire surface as the catalytic active site compared with Pt/C catalysts, AuPd NWs showed excellent charge-transfer electron activity and structural flexibility to achieve excellent ORR activity and stability. Furthermore, to further investigate the effect of defect concentration on material stability and electrochemical properties, Yao and colleagues [82] synthesized porous NiCo2O4 nanoribbons with controlled oxygen defects. The concentration of oxygen defects in the nanoribbon can be regulated by fine-tuning the annealing temperature and time. Appropriate concentrations of oxygen vacancies contribute to regulating the electronic state, further provide an effective electrocatalytic active site, stimulate the adsorption capacity of OHâ, and significantly improve the catalytic activity and electrochemical stability of OER. 6.2 Design rules for defective active sites in batteries 6.2.1 Optimizing the active site It is well known that the number of active sites is a key factor in determining the electrocatalytic properties. To design cells with excellent electrochemical properties, we are supposed to not only increase the number of active sites, but also improve the utilization of the active sites. Introducing defects into the electrocatalyst can increase the number of active sites of the material. Both experimental and theoretical results suggest that most of the active sites for two-dimensional materials are located in marginal regions rather than their base surfaces. To design two-dimensional electrocatalysts with more edge active sites, defects can be introduced at the edge of the material. Improving the utilization of the active site is also one of the strategies to improve electrochemical performance. For example, atomic-level dispersed electrocatalysts attract much attention due to their maximum active site availability and a uniform coordination environment [89]. To stabilize the metal center dispersed at the atomic scale, carbon materials are often used as substrate materials in electrocatalysts. Carbon material with rich defect sites can provide large amounts of vacancies, and the combination of atomic-level dispersed electrocatalysts not only has good atomic stability, but also has high catalytic activity against electrochemical reactions. In addition, the concentration of defects in the reasonable design of electrocatalysts is also one of the design principles to improve the electrochemical performance of batteries. Yu et al. [90] enhancing electrocatalysis through precise oxygen vacancy modulation and control. Adjusting the oxygen vacancy concentration by changing the Ni/Co ratio in the alloy favors the formation of more active sites on the surface and edges of the defective spinel structure, activating the surrounding atoms to increase the active site reactivity. In contrast, excess oxygen vacancies inhibit the OER. The electronic structure of the active site is optimized to facilitate the moderate adsorption energy of the oxygen intermediates, reduce the barrier of the oxygen electrode reaction, and improve the intrinsic activity of the catalyst. The oxygen vacancy of f-Ni0.1Co0.9O x can not only provide more active sites, but also can adjust the electronic structure and reduce the energy barrier of the intermediates [90]. Uncoordinated NiâO and CoâO bonds would introduce oxygen vacancies, causing more unsaturated electronic structures at the catalyst/reactant interface, thus allowing for easy formation of intermediates or absorbers to accelerate the reaction kinetics. 6.2.2 Increasing the stability of the structure In the electrochemical processes, the valence state of the metal is prone to change, and the metal nanoparticles are easy to gather, leading to changes in the structure and activity of the catalyst. Under strong polarization, the nanoparticles may undergo an amorphous phase transition process to reduce the stability of the catalyst. Therefore, the design of excellent bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts should have a large specific surface area, high porosity and hierarchical porous structure that can expose more ORR and OER active sites. What's more, the high-conductance network structure can also accelerate mass transfer and fast charge transfer. The reasonably designed catalyst structure can reduce the impedance of the electrode interface, and improve the electronic conductivity, and the electrocatalytic activity and stability of the electrode. In addition, mechanical flexibility makes it a potential application of flexible solid-air batteries. For transition metal-based materials, the electrochemical activity also depends on the structural design. In contrast to crystal TMO, defective oxides have a flexible, disordered lattice structure, which tends to increase the catalytic active site and promote electron transfer [90]. Due to the reversible and flexible structure of the active substances, the f-Ni0.1Co0.9O x electrocatalyst can be stable before and after the OER, which is of great significance for the hundreds of service cycles in the commercial applications of energy storage. 6.2.3 DFT computational to explore efficient catalysts Usually, the ORR and the OER have different requirements for the active site, it is difficult for one catalyst to exhibit two excellent electrochemical properties. It is particularly urgent to explore new multifunctional electrocatalysts. The DFT calculations can be used to understand the origin of the active site, and to explain the electrocatalytic reaction pathway in the chemical conversion reactions [91]. In addition to exploring the mechanism of the catalytic reaction, DFT calculations can also provide guidance in the search for new catalysts [92]. The most stable configuration and the reaction mechanism of the unsynthesized electrocatalysts can be determined by DFT calculations, which provide a direction for determining the atomic structure and properties of the unsynthesized electrocatalysts. Large-scale DFT calculations before synthesis can predict the performance of new materials, thereby reducing time consumption and study costs [93]. For defect electrocatalysts, the modified electron density after the introduction of multidimensional defects in the lattice is one of the important strategies to enhance the electrocatalytic performance, and the efficient defect electrocatalysts can be explored through DFT calculation. 7 Application of defects in batteries To satisfy the growing demand for energy storage devices for hybrid electric vehicles and electronic devices in recent years, related electrocatalytic materials have aroused great enthusiasm from researchers, which have a high energy density, good catalytic activity, and long-term stability. Although different types of energy storage devices have different structures and energy storage mechanisms, their electrochemical mechanism and basic composition are similar. Electrode materials play a pivotal role in the process of exerting the performance of energy storage equipment. Therefore, the exploration and development of advanced electrode materials with special structure and morphology and excellent electrochemical properties have always been the goal of our progress. The introduction of defects in electrocatalytic materials has always been one of the most striking and effective strategies. Previous results showed that the electronic structure and charge distribution of the electrode material are significantly altered when the catalyst is introduced into defects. Furthermore, vacancy and heteroatomic-doping defects can be beneficial for increasing the active site during the reaction and increasing the energy density of the electrocatalyst. In this section, we review the recent research advances in the field of various rechargeable batteries (Li-S batteries, Li-O2 batteries, and ZABs from the intrinsic defects, anion/cation vacancies, lattice distortion, heteroatom doping, and so on. Table 1 shows the ORR and OER bifunctional activity of recently reported defected electrocatalysts and Table 2 exhibits the research progress of metal defective materials in the metal batteries. Table 3 is the comparison of metal-S battery performances based on Electrocatalyst with different defect types. It appears from Tables 1â3 that metal defective materials not only have excellent bifunctional catalytic activity, but also are perfectly applied in metal-based batteries. 7.1 Zn-air battery ZABs are one of the most promising metal-air battery technologies because of their superior theoretical energy density, safety, and abundant zinc reserves [94]. Unfortunately, the slow dynamics of the ORR and OER of the air electrodes severely hinder the actual commercialization of ZABs. Defective engineering in ZAB electrode materials helps to expose the active site and edges of catalysts, which is beneficial to improve the OER/ORR electrochemical properties. 7.1.1 Intrinsic defects The intrinsic defect refers to the region where the atomic arrangement is periodically damaged, although it does not contain foreign dopants. Along with the unceasing research, the study of intrinsic defects mainly focuses on carbon-based materials, which include edge defects and topological defects. The proper design of the intrinsic defects in the carbon skeleton can affect the overall charge state, increase the density of the active sites, and thus improve the electrocatalytic properties. Moreover, carbon-based materials have been widely used to promote ORR, mainly because of their outstanding cycling stability, large specific surface area and good electrical conductivity [95â98]. Combined with the structural advantages of intrinsic carbon defects, carbon-based composites with rich intrinsic defects have broad applications in various energy storage device. In this section, we will summarize the application and recent progress of composites with rich intrinsic defects in Zn-air battery. Graphene is widely used in the electrochemical energy storage field as a result of its unique frame structure and its properties as substrates modified by various atoms or groups [99â103]. What is more, graphene materials promote slow reaction kinetics and good conductivity, which also make them shine in the field of electrocatalysis. For example, Wang et al. [104] prepared N, S, and P tri-doped graphene (NSP-Gra) by ball milling combined with in-situ pyrolysis to introduce defects. The morphology of the initial graphene and heteroatoms doped graphene is surveyed by TEM in Fig. 18(a) . The NSP-Gra exhibit obvious lattice fringe in Regions 1 and 2 (Fig. 18(c)). The LSV curves are measured at a rotation rate of 1600 r minâ1, and plotted in Fig. 18(b). For N and S double-doped graphene (NS-Gra), it represents a more positive onset potential, which exhibits a superior positive onset potential of 0.95 V and half-wave potential of 0.82 V. What's more, NSP-Gra gives a potential of 1.76 V at the current density of 10 mA cmâ2, showing outstanding bifunctional ORR/OER catalytic activity. Beyond this, the synthesized NSP-Gra not only exhibited good stability over more than 5000 cycles in ZABs, but also provided high power densities up to 225 mW cmâ2. Topological defects are usually present in carbon skeletons in non-hexagonal structures such as pentagons, hexagons, and octagons. The introduction of topological defects can interfere with the electronic symmetry of the aromatic ring, causing a local charge redistribution, and the adjacent carbon atoms can be optimized as the active sites of the electrocatalysts. The application of topological defects in transition metal phthalocyanines has attracted extensive focus, which can change the charge distribution and surface chemical properties of carbon-based materials [105â108]. When contact occurs between metal atoms (e.g. Fe atoms) and the defects of the carbon material, the electrons in the defect site are transferred to the metal atom to form an electron-rich region [109]. The process is shown in Fig. 19(a) , when the FePc suspension falls into the DG suspension, the coupling enhancement of DG and FePc is mainly due to electron-rich defects and electron-deficient Fe atoms through the ÏâÏ superposition between large conjugated rings. Therefore, FePc and DG are closely combined to form FePc/DG hybrid. As displayed in Fig. 19(b), FePc/DG hybrid shows a 2D planar structure with a crude surface. The FePc sheets on the surface of the DG are nanosized (Fig. 19(c)). Besides, the EDS mapping displays a well-distributed of C, N, and Fe in the ultrathin 2D nanosheets (Fig. 19(d)). By coupling FePc with DG via ÏâÏ stacking, the strong chemical and electronic coupling between electron-rich defects and electron-deficient Fe atoms avoid the re-aggregation of FePc, exposing more active Fe sites. Therefore, ultrathin 2D nanosheets stabilized by FePc/DG can adequately expose more active sites to enhance ORR performance. The ZABs assembled by the as-prepared FePc/DG not only showed excellent ORR catalytic activity and outstanding cycling stability, but also the half-wave potential at an alkaline solution (0.90 V vs. RHE), which was more active than that of the Pt/C catalyst (0.86 V vs. RHE). The defects in the above carbon materials are called 585 defects. It is confirmed by the first principal calculations that 585 defects on graphene have more influence on ORR than N-doping [110]. In addition, experimental results also show that graphene with G585 defects can promote oxygen adsorption and accelerate the slow redox reaction of electrode materials [111]. The edge defects fill the edge of the material with large numbers of unmatched electrons, which can effectively accelerate the electron transfer and reduce the formation energy of key intermediates [112]. Meanwhile, the edge carbon atoms exhibit a higher charge density and can be used as an active site. Such as graphene material armchairs and zigzag-oriented edge structures. The decrease in the number of edges hanging bonds in graphene structure leads to the reconstruction of active edge atoms [113â115]. Edge defects may occur when the energy of edge atoms is below the threshold of replacing atoms from perfect graphene, and the edges of armchairs can be converted to zigzag edges [116,117]. Therefore, the graphene edge structure can be deemed defective. An intelligible case of edge defects is that when a carbon atom is removed from a zigzag edge, the edges form a pentagon in the middle of a row of hexagons at the edge, while other edge reconstructions lead to a combination of pentagonal and heptagonal carbon structures at the edges, as shown in Fig. 20 . ORR performances of edges and basal surfaces in pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) materials were investigated by Wang and his colleagues [118]. As shown in Fig. 21(a) , electrolytic devices include working electrodes, electrolytes, reverse electrodes and reference electrodes. Droplets were tested at the edge (Fig. 21(b) and basal surface (Fig. 21(c)), and the results showed that the HOPG edge was livelier than the base surface. The reason why the ORR activity of the HOPG edge structure is so high is that the charge distribution of edge carbon atoms is dense from DFT calculations. It can be seen that graphene edge defect structure has great potential in the field of electrocatalysts. Based on edge defects, modified carbon materials, especially halogenated graphene, also exhibit enhanced ORR activity [119â124]. Zhang et al. [125] used the photochlorination method to design the structural defects and covalent CACl bonds in graphene, which has outstanding bifunctional OER and ORR properties. Photo chlorination caused more edge structural defects to increase active sites, which has prominent OER electrocatalytic properties according to lower initial potentialand, a smaller Tafel slope. What's more, graphite chloride emerges cycling stability for more than 108 cycles in the electrode materials used as ZABs, which is excelled noble metal-based ZABs. 7.1.2 Anion/cation vacancy Vacancies have been called the most accessible defects that exist in electrode materials, which are the spaces left by the atoms or ions in the crystal after their leaving [126]. As reported, anion/cation vacancy defects could appear alone or simultaneously in material to achieve the most stable structure (Fig. 22 ) [127]. It not only heightens the electrochemical performance of the materials, but also improves the catalytic activity of electrocatalysts. What's more, anion/cation defects exert an enormous function on the electronic structure and surface properties of transition metal-based materials [128â130]. And defects in transition metals can act as active sites for OER and ORR to promote electrocatalytic reactions in electrode materials. Cation vacancies can promote electrocatalytic reactions because unsaturated atoms appear on the surface of materials when cation vacancies exist [131]. Cation defects are mainly found in rare metals such as ruthenium and iridium, or transition metals such as Fe, Co and Ni, and their oxides. As reported, the researchers focused on iron, cobalt, nickel and manganese-based materials and their decent oxide hydroxides and composites. A low concentration of metal defects can affect the electronic structure of electrode materials and increase the number of active sites for the reaction [132]. It is the main reason that the metal defects will reduce the band gap near the Fermi level and increase the charge density, which will lead to electron delocalization and the improvement of conductivity [133,134]. Moreover, adsorption capacity and activation of oxygen by electrode materials are enhanced due to the active cations occupying more Ï* orbitals [135â137] and decreasing the activation energy barrier [138]. Therefore, in virtue of two important factors affecting the property of ORR catalysts are oxygen adsorption capacity and electrical conductivity, defects can be introduced into electrocatalysts to improve ORR activity. Transition metal-based oxides (TMOs), especially Fe, Co, and Mn, are widely used in ZABs because of their special electronic structure [139]. However, the further development of TMOs in ZABs is limited by the lower electrical conductivity and poor intrinsic activity [140,141]. At present, materials with defects are gradually being discovered by researchers in ZABs, which can be used as electrocatalytic materials with high electrical conductivity and chemical activity [142]. Among them, rich-defective manganese and its oxides not only have large storage capacity, low price, and little toxicity, but also as different amounts of electrons are added to fill the orbits of manganese ions, their d band centers near the Fermi level also change accordingly. Hence the multiplicity of valence states and structural variability of manganese ions make manganese-based materials have great potential in the field of electrocatalysts [143â145]. Zhang et al. [146] prepared the Mn3O4 of manganese defects by hot synthesis and hot calcination of manganese glycerol solution. The half-wave potential of normal and defected Mn3O4 are 0.62 and 0.65 V, respectively (Fig. 23(a) ). The experimental and analytical results showed that the manganese defects in the Mn3O4 made the electronic structure change to increase the conductivity and the electronic degree of freedom (Figs. 23(c,d)), which not only provided more Mn3+ as the main active sites, but also promoted the absorption of O2 and the desorption of OH* (Fig. 23(g)). Besides, the free energy in the speed limit step was reduced as shown in Fig. 23(b). In addition to manganese-based materials, metal defects are common in cobalt-containing composites. For example, Peng et al. [147] reported a binder-free porous carbon nanofiber (N-Co/CNF) cathode for ZABs synthesized by plasma etching. After plasma etching treatment, not only more metal defects and active sites were introduced, but also the composite has a stable structure, which shows quite high ORR electrocatalytic activity. Furthermore, a non-adhesive structure provides a diffusion channel for the rapid transport of O2 and electrolytes. Hence, the integrated cathode has the advantages of high specific capacity, great energy density and long-term durability for ORR/OER. In the transition interface of metal composites, there are also defects. For example, Li et al. [148] found that in the transition interface of nickel NiO/CoO composites, there were coordination defects that can accelerate the OER/ORR reaction, which can be regarded as the main active sites. DFT calculations showed that the ultrahigh electron transfer rate comes from the interfacial region (Figs. 24(aâc) ), which led to strong electron transfer getting over the coulombic barrier. It was valid that dâd coupling via NiâNi or CoâCo co-ordinational defects, which further led to an active t2g (Fig. 24(d)). This preliminarily proposed a universal way to optimal OER property, and contributed to reversible ORR reaction. Importantly, NiO/CoO TINWs exhibited an outstanding overall electrode performance with the lowest ÎE (0.682 V) (Fig. 24(e)). NiO/CoO TINWs were further used as the air-cathode of primary ZABs with 6.0 mol Lâ1 KOH aqueous as the electrolyte. As shown in Fig. 24(f), these primary ZABs with large open-circuit voltage (OCV = 1.492 V) delivered a maximum power density of about 151 mW cmâ2, larger than NiCo2O4 NWs (67 mW cmâ2) and Pt/C + IrO2 (112 mW cmâ2). The application of NiO/CoO TINWs as an air cathode in ZABs had a large specific capacity of up to 842.58 mAh gZn â1. The energy density was 996.44 Wh kgZn â1 and is stable for 33 h at 25 Â°C as shown in Fig. 24(g). Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) as OER electrocatalysts have brought about widespread attention on account of their adjustable chemical component and distinct electronic structure. NiFe LDHs are deemed as a prominent OER electrocatalyst since the cooperation of adjustable Ni2+ and Fe3+ [149]. Nevertheless, the insufficient activity of reaction sites on the surface of NiFe LDHs nanosheets leads to a decrease in OER performance.
