The introduction of metal cation vacancy defects can overcome this shortcoming due to the multiplicity of valence states and stable orbital distribution of metal cations [150]. And previous research has demonstrated that the introduction of cation vacancies can availably excite the affirmative influences on the electrocatalytic performance of metal compounds [151]. For instance, the introduction of iron or nickel vacancy defects effectually regulates the surface electronic structure of NiFe LDHs nanosheets and increases the adsorption capacity of materials OER intermediates to oxygen. DFT calculations show that iron or nickel vacancy defects have great potential to improve NiFe LDHs oxygen catalytic activity [152]. Zhou et al. [131] exfoliated layered double hydroxides by acid etching, which contains a large number of Co, Fe and multiple defects including O vacancies. Acid etching ameliorates the electronic structure of layered double hydroxide materials and provides more active reaction sites, which lead to ultralong cycling stability and OER catalytic activity. Moreover, the as-prepared layered double hydroxide nanoparticles have been applied as bifunctional electrocatalysts for rechargeable ZABs [153]. The integral performance of the battery is not only predominant to the corresponding battery by applying an IrO2 and Pt/C mixture as the cathode, but also has a low voltage gap (1.0 V at 25 mA cmâ2) and long-range cycling stability (over 80 h). Besides cationic vacancies, anionic vacancies in transition metals are also frequently investigated to improve electrocatalytic performance [154,155]. Similarly, anionic vacancies can observably regulate the electrochemical properties of the material surface and accelerate the transport efficiency of electrons, thus mentioning the conductivity of the material. Among them, oxygen vacancies are considered to be a major method to improve the electrocatalytic performance of materials because of their comparatively low formation energy and the high rate of absorption and desorption for intermediates [156â160]. During the process of ORR/OER, the augment of electron density of adjacent metal atoms caused by oxygen vacancies can enhance the conductivity of transition metal oxides and increase the rate of charge transfer [161,162]. For example, an appropriate concentration of oxygen vacancies reliably exerts an enormous function on the OER property of transition oxides [163â165]. Previous researches state clearly that the introduction of oxygen vacancies in perovskite is a valid method to change the valence and electronic structure of transition metals, which can enhance the catalytic performance of OER/ORR [166â168]. Perovskite is a potential and multifunctional material, which has a high catalytic activity against ORR, OER, and HER, so it has been widely used in M-S or metal-air batteries. Perovskite can usually be represented by a general formula of ABO3, where A represents rare earth or alkaline-earth metal cation, and B represents a transition metal cation. Oxygen vacancies were introduced into sites A or B to obtain optimized electrochemical properties [169]. For example, a series of bifunctional composites with excellent electrochemical activity and durability were synthesized using the perovskite Sr(Co0.8Fe0.2)0.95 P0.05O3 (SCFP) [170]. As shown in Fig. 25(a) , the SCFP and Pt particles evenly dispersed over the carbon particles at small distances, which would facilitate the formation of strong interactions between the two phases. In the composites, Pt-SCFP/C-12 showed the most positive onset potential (E onset = 0.90 V) and half-wave potential (E 1/2 = 0.81 V), which were also significantly superior to those of parental SCFP and the ORR performance is almost close to 20% Pt/C (Fig. 25(b)). The ZAB bound to Pt-SCFP/C-12 showed a peak power density of 122 mW cmâ2 at 214 mA cmâ2, far exceeding that of 81 mW cmâ2 for 20% Pt/C as shown in Fig. 25(d). Constant current charge and discharge cycles were tested at 5 mA cmâ2 to evaluate the long-term battery performance and efficiency of continuous cycles. Compared to 1:1 20% Pt/C + IrO2, the rechargeable composite Pt-SCFP/C-12 showed excellent discharging and charging potential in mixture-based ZAB (Fig. 25(e)). In addition, batteries with Pt-SCFP/C-12 also showed excellent charge-discharge cycle stability within 80 hours (240 cycles), superior to batteries based on a mixture of 1:1 20% Pt/C + IrO2. Apart from the ORR activity, high concentrations of oxygen vacancies have the same effect on OER as it can debase the Helmholtz free energy of O* translated into OOH* in steps of speed limit requirements [171,172]. Tian Y et al. [173] employed DFT calculations to prove that the introduction of oxygen vacancies on the surface of Co (II) oxide (CoO) can observably debase the energy barrier in the steps of the speed limit of ORR and OER. Meanwhile, Co(OH)2 was calcined into CoO (ODAC-CoO) nanosheets in a vacuum, which exhibited outstanding electrocatalytic activity for both ORR and OER. The calcined samples showed large capacity, high power density and long cycling stability when used as the cathode of ZABs. Moreover, oxygen vacancies can accelerate the reaction kinetics of reactants and reaction intermediates, which is the active sites involved in the reaction process [174,175]. Ni/Co-based bimetallic oxides exhibit a much higher OER/ORR bifunctional catalytic activity due to their abundant active site and oxygen vacancies. Liu et al. [176] synthesized NiCo-bimetallic oxide supported on carbon nanofibers by electrospinning technology, which is a potential bifunctional catalyst. The synthetic process of the NiCo2O@C catalyst is shown in Fig. 26(a) . The PVP decomposes into N,O-doped carbon fibers with the help of acetamide and thiourea, and the release of water and carbon dioxide can form a large number of defects in the carbon fiber. The structure of the nanofiber surface is rough and covered with nanoparticles, which can effectively increase the contact area between the catalyst and the electrolyte (Fig. 26(b)). There are numerous interfacial domains between the two different crystals. Given that NiCo2O@C has different crystal structures, a large number of defects are distributed near the interface domain (marked by the yellow circle in Fig. 26(c)), confirming the defect structure of NiCo2O@C. A large number of defects within the interface can be considered atomic traps that would favor the adsorption of more oxygen intermediates and have a positive effect on the charge transfer within the active site. A variety of oxygen vacancies have been introduced to the surface of NiCo-based bimetallic oxides, which shows that the NiCo2O@C (0.69 V) is much less than the commercial Pt/C-IrO2 (0.78 V), showing higher OER/ORR bifunctional catalytic activity [177,178]. In addition, the ZAB assembled with the synthesized catalyst has high power density and superior cycling stability (running continuously for more than 1500 h), which is more advantageous to the Pt/C-IrO2 hybrid catalyst (Fig. 26(f)). It is well known that efficacious methods to improve the performance of catalysts enable the regulation of charge distribution on the surface of materials and the adsorption of reactants or intermediates [179,180]. Among them, the interface between composites is widely used in electrocatalysts because of the synergistic effect and charge transfer, and the adsorption transfer of intermediates can be strengthened [181â183]. Anion vacancy defects can be used as active sites at the heterointerfaces, thus improving the performance of the catalyst [142]. Li et al. [184] introduced a large number of oxygen vacancies into the CoP/CeO2 heterointerface structure, which has an extremely low potential of about 224 mV in alkaline media at 10 mA cmâ2. Catalysts containing heterointerface structures not only display better OER properties than catalysts with a single component (CoP, CeO2, and RuO2), but also can operate stably for exceeding 500 cycles in the application of rechargeable ZABs, and power density is higher than that of current commercial ZABs. In addition to oxygen vacancy defects, the introduction of sulfur vacancy defects is often an effective method to improve the activity of metal sulfide electrocatalysts [185â187]. Yin et al. [188] reported an abnormal NiS2/CoS2 nanowires electrocatalytic material with nanointerface, slight sulfur vacancy and abundant oxygen vacancies. The electrochemical results show that the atom-level coupled nanointerfaces composed of Cu, Ni and S atoms produce a great number of active sites that can improve bifunctional catalysis due to lattice distortion caused by cation doping and oxygen vacancies introduced by NiS2/CoS2. 7.1.3 Lattice distortion The lattice distortion is caused by the appearance of defects that destroy the equilibrium state between atoms, distort the lattice and leave the initial position [189]. And the lattice distortion can change the structure of the surface charge and increase the potential energy, which will affect a series of physical and chemical properties of the crystal [190â192]. Besides regulating the electronic structure, the lattice distortion also promotes the formation of oxygen vacancy defects and the ability of energy migration, which is an important factor affecting the transport rate of oxygen vacancy defects [193â195]. The effective adjustment of the electronic structure through lattice distortion can change the surface adsorption of intermediates in the rate-limiting step and also increase the rate of proton-electron transfer in the reaction [196]. Liu and co-workers [197] prepared non-noble metal MOFs with lattice distortion by low-temperature hydrothermal method, which has efficient bifunctional ORR and OER catalytic activity. Lattice distortion adjusts the O 2p band and leads to a change in the covalent bond of the NiO bond, thereby enhancing the catalytic performance of the material. The optimized NiFe MOF exhibited higher ORR and OER properties than the original NiFe MOF, which has great potential in the field of rechargeable ZABs. Recently, transition metals and their derived alloys have been extensively studied as potential candidates for ORR and OER electrocatalysts. For bimetallic catalysts, the intrinsic polarization between two different metals can be used to enhance charge transfer and facilitate catalytic reactions. But primitive bimetallic catalysts often exhibit only a single catalytic activity. The most common strategy for preparing catalysts with bifunctional functions is to realize defect engineering by crystal structure modification to improve the active surface site of the electrocatalyst. It aims to regulate heterostructures to optimize charge distribution and conductivity. The changes in the lattice structure and lattice distortion induce electronic interactions to improve the electrocatalytic properties. It is reported that the surface of the electrocatalyst material will produce lattice distortion when the cation concentration exceeds the limit. For instance, Chen et al. [198] synthesized an electrocatalyst by plasma engineering, which is Fe-rich with nitrogen-doped carbon intermetallic nanoparticle (Fe-enriched-FeNi3/NC). The high concentration of Fe ions in the electrocatalyst causes lattice distortion and produces a large number of oxygen active sites, which exhibits outstanding bifunctional catalytic activity in suitable alkaline electrolytes. According to DFT, the lattice distortion of Fe-enriched-FeNi3/NC material increases the free charge density near the Fermi level, thus showing excellent ORR and OER performance when acting as an air cathode for ZABs with high power density (89 mW cmâ2) and large battery capacity (734 mAh gâ1), even superior to that of Pt/C-Ir/C batteries. Similarly, the regulation of cation/anion ratios is one of the commonly used methods to establish delicacy lattice distortions to augment the number of active sites and enhance the catalytic performance of electrocatalysts [199â202]. Zheng et al. [203] constructed Ni x Co1âx Se2âx Se2-O interfaces containing oxygen vacancies and delicacy lattice distortions, showing excellent bifunctional catalytic activity in ORR and OER. Since Ni and Co are atoms in adjacent positions in the periodic table and the atomic radius and electronic structure of them are similar, so the atomic ratio in the Ni x Co1âx Se2 structure can be adjusted to produce the desired delicacy lattice distortion (Figs. 27(a,b) ). In concert, the local unbalanced force caused by lattice distortion also leads to the degree of lattice distortion, which provides more active sites for catalytic reaction (Fig. 27(c)). The experimental results show that the method of regulating the concentration ratio of Ni/Co in Ni x Co1âx Se2 interface materials has great potential in the field of synthesizing electrocatalysts. The LSV curve of Ni0.6Co0.4Se2-O (Fig. 27(d)) for OER shows a small overpotential of 285 mV to reach 10 mA cmâ2, about 78, 133, 177, and 99 mV lower than those of Ni0.6Co0.4Se2, NiSe2, CoSe2 and commercial Ir/C (20%), respectively. For the stability test of Ni0.6Co0.4Se2-O (Fig. 27(e)), the LSV results showed no significant change even after 1000 CV cycles, only about 2.6% of current decay within 72 h, and more stable than that of Ir/C used for OER reactions in alkaline electrolytes. As shown in Fig. 27(f), Ni0.6Co0.4Se2-O displays a smaller onset potential that is only 40 mV larger than Pt/C (20%) counterpart, with a diffusion limiting current density of 5.31 mA cmâ2. The galvanostatic discharge curves (Fig. 27(g)) for Ni0.6Co0.4Se2-O and Pt@Ir/C at 10 mA cmâ2 were texted with voltage plateaus of 1.28 and 1.26 V, and the specific capacities are 738 and 652 mAh gZn â1 and energy densities is 944 and 821 Wh kgZn â1, respectively. In addition, the Ni0.6Co0.4Se2-O exhibited better cycle stability compared with Pt@Ir/C of only 80 h (Fig. 27(h)). What's more, Ni x Co1âx Se2âx Se2-O materials can provide good stability even under 150 bending when applied to the air electrode for ZAB. From the above example, the interfacial engineering of transition metal catalysts can greatly increase the number of active sites of electrocatalysts and enhance the rate of electronic transfer, thereby increasing the activity of electrocatalysis [204â206]. Besides, more studies have found that the strong electron interaction in the heterointerface structure could enormously regulate the electronic structure and electrochemical properties of the material interface or surface [207â211]. Cao et al. [212] prepared NiS2/CoS2 nano-compounds with heterogeneous interfaces by continuous ion implantation. Because of the delicacy lattice distortion at the NiS2/CoS2 heterogeneous interface, the catalytic performance and electron transport efficiency of NiS2/CoS2 are larger than those of single component materials in alkaline electrolytes. In addition, the NiS2/CoS2 as the air cathode for the ZAB has a high-power density (101 mW cmâ2) and large battery capacity (734 mAh gâ1). A deep understanding of the lattice distortion of the John-Taylor effect accumulates researchers to design efficient and appropriate bifunctional electrocatalysts. It is of great significance to design appropriate and active bifunctional catalysts. Studying how to improve the kinetics of calcium manganate (CMO) reaction is an important method to improve its OER/ORR catalytic performance, mainly on account of the weak interaction between active sites and oxygen intermediates. Yang et al. [213] constructed the MnO6 of octahedral distortion to improve the absorption ability of intermediates by heat-induced method, which can largely enhance the catalytic performance of CMO. Jahn-teller distortion effect in the MnO6 structure can redistribute the electrons on the surface of the material and increase the rate of electron transfer between active sites and oxygen, thus improving the electrocatalytic performance of the distorted CMO (D-CMO). It's worth noting that D-CMO has great potential in the production of high-property ZABs with excellent mechanical strength due to satisfactory bifunctional electrocatalytic activity, which shows a significant open circuit voltage of 1.46 V with and a maximum power density of 149 mW cmâ2, even exceeding the currently commercially available noble metal-based batteries. Moreover, there are often one or more factors affecting the performance of electrocatalysts, such as crystal structure, vacancy, and lattice defects. For instance, An et al. [214] reported a CuS/NiS2 catalyst with atomically coupled nanointerfaces, which have delicate lattice distortions and numerous vacancy defects. Experimental results show that the synthesized CuS/NiS2 catalysts possess efficient bifunctional catalytic activity because of the weak Jahn-Teller effect in the structure, lattice distortion caused by the coupled interface and obvious vacancy defects as reaction sites (Fig. 28(a) ), which atomic alignment aberration INs were 14.7%. Furthermore, the fast Fourier transform (FFT) in the Fig. 28(a) shows that subtle atomic arrangement distortions can provide the active site for improved catalytic performance. The ESR spectra (Fig. 28(b)) further illustrate the high S-vacancy density of CuS/NiS2 INs. Fig. 28(c) is a schematic diagram of lattice distortion and vacancies at the CuS/NiS2 atomic nanointerfaces, which can promote the generation of more active sites and enhance catalytic properties by reducing surface energy. The structural information of the vacancy defects and the Jahn-Teller effects of Cu and Ni is shown in Figs. 28(d,e). Moreover, when CuS/NiS2 interface nanocrystals are used as air electrodes in ZABs, it showed the power density of up to 172.4 mW cmâ2 (Fig. 28(f)). 7.1.4 Heteroatom doping Extrinsic defects, mainly refer to a class of crystal defects produced by foreign particles (impurities) replacing the normal particle position or entering the gap position of the normal node. They are also called impurity defects, which are widely used in special materials and electrodes [215]. At first, the researchers found that nitrogen doping in carbon nanotubes can effectively improve the transport and conversion efficiency of oxygen, reduce the energy barriers of the reaction, and obviously improve the ORR activity of the catalyst [216]. Moreover, the introduction of heteroatoms during the transfer of electrons from the adsorbed OH* to the catalyst results in a large number of O* and OOH* intermediates, thereby increasing the OER activity [217]. When the desired nanocarbon electrocatalysts require high graphitization properties, the doping structure treated at high temperatures is beneficial for graphitization [218â220]. With the in-depth study of the mechanism of heteroatom doping defects, research workers discover that some defective carbon nanomaterials have prodigious ORR activity in 2015, even without doping treatment defects [221â223], which can be equivalent to or indeed better than doped carbon electrocatalysts. Nevertheless, in most cases, defective carbon nanomaterials doped with heteroatoms have higher ORR activity than non-doped carbon materials [224â226]. Studies have shown that most electrocatalytic materials have the highest ORR activity only when dopants combine with defects, revealing that defects and dopants can jointly or synergistically boost the electrocatalytic performance of nanocarbon materials. Hence, the high concentration doping or doping/defect approach is an effective way for carbon-based electrocatalysts to enhance bifunctional ORR/OER performance [227]. Wang et al. [228] synthesized pyridine-N-doped graphene containing plentiful vacancy defects, which explains that the synergistic effect of defects and doping can conspicuously improve the OER activity of the samples (Fig. 29(a) ). The results of DFT show that the number of active sites on the surface of graphene doped with pyridine-N is greatly increased, which the ORR overpotential is 0.28 V and the OER overpotential is 0.28 V (Figs. 29(b,c)). As shown in Fig. 29(d), seven types of pyridinic-N configurations (i.e., 1N, 2N, 3N-1, 3N-2, 4N, 5N, and 6N) in the graphene model were built at the edge of the graphene vacancy defect. Fig. 29(e) shows that the 4N (tetrapyridine N) has the lowest overpotential of 0.28/0.28 V, while the overpotential at the 2N site (0.33 V) is comparatively higher than the 4N (0.28 V) for OER. As shown in Fig. 29(f), the overpotential of NDGs-800 at a current density of 10 mA cmâ2 is 0.76 V, only slightly greater than the Pt/C + Ir/C composite (0.68 V), indicating a highly efficient reversible rechargeable ZAB. As shown in Fig. 29(g), the voltage remains stable for more than 78 h at a constant current density of 10 mA cmâ2 for 20 min per cycle (up to 234 cycles), in contrast, Pt/C + Ir/C showed rapid activity decay under the same conditions. The power density of NDGs-800 is up to 115.2 mW cmâ2 and the maximum energy density is 872.3 Wh kgâ1 when used as cathode electrode material for ZAB in alkaline electrolytes. Similar to N atoms, O, Cl, P, and B heteroatoms can also modulate the electron distribution of carbon materials as a result of different electronegativity with carbon atoms, thus reducing the adsorption energy of intermediates to achieve high-performance ORR activity [229]. Recently, researchers have proposed to introduce two heteroatoms into carbon materials to constrict co-doped carbon nanomaterials. Compared with single doping, B [230], S [231â233] or P [234] and N co-doped nanocarbon catalysts [235,236] have more potential in ORR activity, and O [237] or P [238] and N co-doping have a positive influence on the OER activity. The main reason is that the coordination effect between dopants redistributes the charge on the surface of nanocarbon materials and exposes more active sites. Yang et al. [239] converted glucose into N, P co-doped foam-type carbon materials (NPG-1000) in an atmosphere of urea and vegetable acids. The N and P double-doped carbon-rich in edges, defects and graphite nitrogen dopants can be able to act synergistically, compared to disordered carbon containing only N-dopant sites and phytate-activated carbon-rich in P-dopants. Moreover, the N and P co-doped carbon with appropriate porous structures as ZAB electrocatalysts with a high discharge power density of 145 mW cmâ2, good stability can effectively improve battery performance, highlighting its potential. Sun et al. [240] have proved that the construction of B, N co-doped nanocarbon is one of the important methods to realize efficient ORR and OER bifunctional catalytic activity. Owing to the coordination effect of the porous structure, heteroatom doping and a large number of carbon defects, the B, N carbon material has high ORR/OER activity and excellent stability compared to Pt/C and RuO2. Impressively, when B, N co-doped carbon is used as the air cathode of the ZAB, it shows a low voltage gap during the charge-discharge process and better cycle stability compared to the current commercial ZAB. 7.2 Li-S battery With the rapid development of science and technology and the improvement of people's living standards, the increasingly prominent environmental and resource problems are becoming more and more concerned for society. Li-S batteries stand out among next-generation energy storage systems due to their excellent cost-effectiveness and environmental friendliness, with eximious theoretical capacity (1672 mAh gâ1) and high theoretical capacity density (2600 Wh kgâ1) [241]. However, during the circulation process, the S/Li2S will undergo volume expansion/contraction (about 80%), leading to the collapse and pulverization of the positive electrode structure [242]. More importantly, the severe polysulfide shuttle effect will reduce the cycle stability of Li-S batteries [243]. To make matters worse, when the precipitated Li2S/Li2S2 is unevenly dispersed on the cathode surface, it easily leads to an inert layer in the cathode, thus reducing the coulombic efficiency [244]. Overall, these problems will inevitably bring about low sulfur utilization and fast capacity attenuation. 7.2.1 Intrinsic defects The adsorption and catalytic capabilities of Li-S batteries largely depend on the local electronic structure of the nanomaterials [245]. The introduction of intrinsic defects can not only allow relatively precise control of atomic distribution and electronic structure. And it is expected to capture polysulfide mediators and reduce the shuttling effect [246]. Moreover, the defects are conducive to exposing the active lattice and edge position of the cathode material, and decrease the degree of uneven decomposition of Li2S/Li2S2. Carbon materials, such as carbon black (CB), graphene, and carbon nanotubes, serve as carriers in Li-S batteries due to their excellent electrical conductivity and chemical stability. Cai and his colleagues introduced the defects into the CB by wet-chemistry, which was controlled by regulating the amount of hydrogen peroxide [247]. The synthetic defect-rich CB can not only promote the conversion of polysulfide to Li2S, thus inhibiting the shuttling effect of polysulfide with favorable catalytic activity. Hence, the cathode rate capacity is 783.8 mAh gâ1 at 4C composed of S and defect-rich CB. To further improve the activity of carbon materials, the researchers introduced defects into carbon architecture (CA) by using multifunctional supercritical carbon dioxide (sc CO2) foaming technology and combined with a high resolution and a wide range of advanced analytical techniques for detection [248]. Fig. 30(a) shows the layered pore structure of CA produced by the multifunctional sc CO2 foaming technique, while the sulfur-filled composite still retains the initial form of CA (Fig. 30(b)). It can be seen that CA with layered pores and plentiful sites can be effectively designed using sc CO2 foaming technology, which improves sulfur loading, electrolyte penetration and electrochemical reactions. The authors adjusted the nitrogen ratio of defects by controlling the pyrolysis temperature to regulate the number of defects, which is propitious to customize the activity of the carbon electrocatalyst. With the precipitation capacity of Li2S in different samples calculated from the integral current, it can be seen that CP/CA-2 (145.7 mAh gs â1) is significantly higher than other samples, and the precipitation of circulating Li2S is obviously more complete and uniform (Figs. 30(dâf)). Synchrotron X-ray 3D nano-CT was applied to further probe the distribution of Li2S precipitation in the internal structure of the sample. Compared with CA-1 and CA-3, CA-2 presented a more homogeneous Li2S precipitation (Figs. 30(gâi)), which is consistent with previous kinetic measurements. Furthermore, S/CA-2 exhibited a higher cycle capacity of 913.9 mAh gâ1. The authors removed the N atoms from the CA by regulating the pyrolysis temperature leading to carbon atomic reconstruction, thereby controlling the N content and the number of intrinsic defects. Defects engineering and sc CO2 foaming technology coordinate to enhance the activity of CA. Therefore, carbon electrocatalysts with controllable activity improve the multiplier capacity and long-term cycle stability of Li-S batteries. As an excellent electrocatalyst in Li-S batteries, researchers usually perform a density functional calculation to estimate the interaction between soluble lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and defect graphene, given that graphene growth is accompanied by defects. The discovery of graphene with defects can effectively capture LiPS substances, thus helping to prolong the cycle life. However, a mere analysis of the interaction between LiPSs and the intrinsic defects of graphene cannot determine that the defective graphene can improve the performance of the cathode. Thus, Zhao et al. [249] performed the DFT calculation of each process in the Li-S battery to investigate how defects on graphene act when using Li2S@graphene as an electrode. Fig. 31(a) shows graphene models for perfect graphene and different carbon atomic defects. The combined effect of defects and SW-type defects can reduce the decomposition barrier of the Li2S, thus promoting the Li2S decomposition during the first charge circulation (Fig. 31(c)). And the authors speculate that the defective graphene is the main driving force during the first charging cycle for reducing the activation energy. DFT calculations show that the binding energy of S-C type Li2S molecules with different degrees of carbon atomic deficient graphene is generally higher than that of Li-C type (Fig. 31(b)). The presence of intrinsic defects enhances the binding strength between Li2S and graphene, Li2S molecules prefer to bind via SâC rather than LiâC bonds. Therefore, S atoms are inclined to bind defects on graphene and shape S-doped graphene. As can be seen from Fig. 31(d), S-doped graphene partially suppresses the âshuttle effectâ, increasing the binding energy of soluble polysulfides, and promoting the S8 to Li2S transition with lower RDS energy during discharge. So, it is concluded that the defects in graphene can forthrightly contribute to the excellent electrochemical properties of Li-S batteries. Recently, with the intensive study of Li-S battery electrodes, researchers often use multiple strategies to improve chemical performance. Wang et al. [250] prepared a graphene-oxide electrocatalyst using a dual strategy of interface and defect engineering for Li-S chemistry. The synergistic heterointerface between oxides and graphene accelerates the migration and transformation of LiPSs. Besides, the synergistic effect of carbon defects in graphene and oxygen vacancies in oxides also favors LiPS adsorption, promoting electron transport and Li+ migration. Therefore, the graphene-oxide electrocatalysts with interface and defect engineering have a high electrocatalytic activity to construct efficient, long-life Li-S batteries. To date, the exploration of intrinsic defects in Li-S batteries has been limited to atomic defects, and few works have investigated the effect of antisite intrinsic defects on polysulfide behavior [251]. Li et al. [252] used the strategy of introducing Bi2Te2.7Se0.3 (BTS) on the diaphragm surface, which is to produce antisite intrinsic defects and study the impact of the defects on the property of Li-S batteries. As shown in Fig. 32(a) , the DFT calculations explore the reaction between the LiPSs and the BTS intrinsic defects, demonstrating the contribution of the nuclear interactions between the LiPSs and the Bi'Te. Magnetic sputtering technology is used to control the thickness of the BTS intermediate layer. The cross-section morphology of the BTS intermediate layer is approximately ten of nanometers, and the nanoscale BTS spread evenly on the PP substrate. At the same time, the BTS film did not bestrow all the channels of the PP diaphragm (Fig. 32(c)), and this ultra-thin nanoscale BTS film can impede the decline of the energy density of the battery. It shows that LiPSs during the charging and discharge process can be efficaciously blocked by inherent antisite defects. It is demonstrated that the significantly better reaction kinetics and cycle performance of the batteries with the BT/PP and BTS/PP compartments than those with the PP and C/PP compartments in Figs. 32(d,e). 7.2.2 Anion/cation vacancy The generation of vacancies is considered a fundamental defect engineering strategy to alter the physicochemical properties and electronic structure of materials [34]. Profiting from the abundance of local electrons, vacancies can be used as adsorption and catalytic sites for the fixation and transformation of various intermediates, thus improving the performance of electrocatalysis and rechargeable battery systems [253,254]. Recently, vacancy engineering has stimulated a strong interest in promoting the adsorption/desorption and catalytic transformation of LiPSs in Li-S batteries, which are mainly divided into anion vacancies and cation vacancies [255â258]. At present, vacancies have great prospects in promoting the practical application of Li-S batteries and inspiring material engineering in the field of related energy storage and conversion. It is generally accepted that quantum dots exhibit unique chemical and physical properties due to quantum confinement and edge effects. Ultra-small size gives a high specific surface area to QDs, exposing rich active points, which can effectively improve the immobilization and catalytic transformation of polysulfide. Oxygen vacancies (OVs) are a common anion defect with great potential in the field of electrocatalysis [253,259]. Metal oxides with rich OVs have rich local electrons and improve the conductivity of electrocatalysts [260]. Furthermore, OVs provide the active site for redox reactions by exposing unsaturated coordination sites, and improve the conversion rate of LiPSs to significantly improve the electrochemical properties of Li-S batteries. For example, Zhang et al. [261] loaded rich-OVs Ti n O2nâ1 quantum dots (OV-T n QDs) onto porous carbon nanosheets (PCN) to prepare a catalyst to promote the adsorption, transformation, and immobilization of LiPSs. Oxidation of Ti atoms into quantum dot-sized TiO2 particles by acid etching and H2O2 oxidation, as well as the preserved two-dimensional structure of the carbon layer, then converting TiO2QDs to OV-T n QDs by calcination. Fig. 33(b) shows the optimized configuration of Li2S4 in different lattice planes of T n QDs and Ti3C2T x . As can be seen from Fig. 33(c), the adsorption energy of Li2S4/T n QDs is smaller than Li2S4/Ti3C2T x , indicating that T n QDs prefer to adsorb Li2S4 and form stronger chemical interactions between Li2S4 and T n QDs [262]. Moreover, the introduction of OVs into TnQDs reduces the adsorption energy and shortened the bond length between Li2S4 and T n QDs, illustrating that OVs are contributed to the chemical immobilization of LiPS on T n QDs [263]. Notably, the overpotential of OV-T n QDs@PCN/S (0.32 V) is clearly lower than Ti3C2T x /S (0.44 V), indicating that has less polarization and advances in rapid redox reaction kinetics. As shown in Fig. 33(d), OV-T n QDs@PCN/S has good multiplier performance (672 mAh gâ1 at 2 C) and outstanding long-term stability (capacity retention of 88% after 1000 cycles at 2 C). Prussian blue (PB) as a kind of metal-organic framework material (MOF) with an exposed active site, has high development space in the field of electrochemistry [264]. Furthermore, the OVs generated by PB during carbonization can act as a profitable adsorbent and catalyst for polysulfides. Zhao et al. prepared a rich-OVs amorphous a-Fe3O4âx /GO material as the first diaphragm coating for Li-S batteries with a nanotube interlocking structure [265]. As can be seen from Fig. 34(a) , a-Fe3O4âx /GO has higher graphitization than PB/GO, which the I D/I G value is 1.13. The coat of amorphous structures and rich-OVs not only enhances the adsorption of polysulfides, but also promotes polysulfide conversion [266,267]. The polysulfide shuttle experiment in Fig. 34(b) reveals the ability of the a-Fe3O4âx /GO@PP layer to adsorb the polysulfide. For batteries with a-Fe3O4âx /GO@PP, the left solution remained transparent for 12 h and practically no Li2S6 diffused across the diaphragm, proving the strong physical adsorption capacity of a-Fe3O4âx /GO@PP for polysulfides. Fig. 34(c) exhibits the CV curves of the Li-S batteries with a PP and a-Fe3O4âx /GO@PP diaphragm. It is worth noting that the battery polarization with the a-Fe3O4âx /GO@PP diaphragm was obviously less effective than that with the PP diaphragm. The battery with a-Fe3O4âx /GO@PP maintains a cycle capacity approach to 610 mAh gâ1 after 500 cycles (Fig. 34(d)). Therefore, it can be concluded that OVs in carbon materials alter the local electronic structure and heighten the electrical conductivity of the material. What's more, the OVs can be viewed as additional catalytic active sites to further expedite the conversion of polysulfides. Typically, different types of carbon have been used as the main material for the cathode of Li-S batteries to overcome the disadvantage of low conductivity. But it usually causes heterogeneous nucleation/deposition of lithium and poor contact between lithium and the main body, which inevitably forms lithium dendrites after cycling at high current density. The researchers composed a porous carbon fiber fabric evenly decorated with VC/V2O3âx hybrid nanoparticles to achieve a high-performance Li-S battery, which can inhibit the shuttle effect and the formation of lithium dendrites at the same time [268]. As shown in Fig. 35(a) , the VC/V2O3âx @CT exhibits a lateral shift of the O 1 peaks. The presence of a specific peak (O 4) at 532.2 eV implies the creation of oxygen vacancies [269â271]. The solution with VC/V2O3âx @CT fleetly decolorized and became colorless after 2 h, clearly demonstrating the chemical anchoring ability of VC/V2O3âx nanoparticles to LiPS. The DFT calculation was performed for the structure of the VC/V2O3âx @CT at the atomic level (Figs. 35(câe)). The higher adsorption energy of Li2S6 on V2O3 (104) indicates the better adsorption of oxides compared to LiPSs. It was also found that the capture capacity of the defective oxide phase was stronger (adsorption capacity of â3.65 eV), meaning that oxygen vacancies favor the chemosorption of LiPSs. As shown in Figs. 35(f,g), the VC/V2O3âx @CT subject exhibits a rather low lithium nucleation barrier (9 mV), proving that the abundant V2O3âx is used as a lithium-philic site for homogeneous Li nucleation and that the metal-conducting VC enables rapid charge transfer, resulting in the fast kinetics of the Li+ reaction. In addition, the full battery provides excellent multiplier performance (882 mAh gâ1 at 5 C). Transition metal sulfides (TMSs) are widely believed to serve as a sulfur body to promote the redox reactions of polysulfides, with great potential in the catalysis of Li-S batteries. However, the low conductivity of TMSs is not enough to meet the practical application needs of Li-S batteries [272,273]. The positive charge defects introduced by the sulfur vacancy in the TMS can not only capture polysulfides efficiently, but also dynamically enhance its redox reactions. Zhao et al. [274] have prepared mesoporous Co3S4 hexagonal nanosheets (Co3S4-DHS) with sulfur vacancies, which have significantly enhanced electron conductivity and excellent adsorption capacity of LiPSs. Co3S4-DHS has more porous structures than CVO with the hexagonal sheet shape of CVO (Fig. 36(a) ), which provides a large specific surface area to fully expose the catalytic active site to improve the conversion kinetics of LiPS, and offers the buffer space to accommodate the volume changes of sulfur during circulation. Notably, the sulfur vacancy defect is clearly observed in Fig. 36(b), and is propitious to advance the catalytic activity against polysulfide conversion. Furthermore, it can be found that the charge-discharge voltage difference (ÎE) of the Co3S4-DHS/S-based electrode is less than the Co3S4/S (Fig. 36(c)), explaining faster ion transmission and lesser electrochemical polarization within the Co3S4-DHS/S-based electrode rather than Co3S4/S [275,276]. To better understand the influence of the sulfur vacancies in Co3S4-DHS on the adsorption capacity and electronic structure of LiPS, the DFT calculation was performed based on the simulation results (Fig. 36(d)), The binding energy of Co3S4-DHS to Li2S6 was 1.32 eV, higher than Co3S4 (1.20 eV), verifying that Co3S4-DHS more efficiently anchors LiPS intermediates, thus improving the cycle stability of Co3S4-DHS/S-based electrodes. Among metal compounds, TMPs have great potential in Li-S batteries due to their excellent electronic conductivity, high catalytic activity and lightly modulated electronic structure [277,278]. The introduction of phosphovacancy into TMP is expected to inhibit the shuttle effect in Li-S chemistry and accelerate the redox kinetics in the electrochemical transformation of LiPS. Sun et al. studied the effect of phosphorus vacancy on Li-S batteries by synthesizing CoP with phosphorus vacancy (CoP-Vp) [279]. As shown in Fig. 37(a) , CNT-CoP with different phosphorous was prepared by adjusting the concentration of NaBH4 solution, which can be clearly seen in the TEM plot. The electronic structure of CoP-Vp can immobilize LiPSs and expedite the redox kinetics in LiPSs transformation. Due to the presence of phosphorus vacancies, the S/CNT-CoP-Vp-1M electrode provides a high specific capacity of 804 mAh g â1 at 2 C and reaches 585 mAh g â1 after 300 cycles, which indicates that the phosphovacancies achieve a high utilization rate of S. It can be clearly seen from the 3D charge density difference cross-section (Fig. 37(d)), that both P and Co atoms near the P vacancies are in a state of charge accumulation, testifying that the P vacancies can increase the adsorption capacity of LiPSs. In addition, Gibbs free energy was calculated to research the effect of phosphorus vacancies on LiPS conversion (Fig. 37(e)). The reduced change of Gibbs free energy (ÎG) during continuous reduction indicates that the electrochemical reaction ÎG from S8 to Li2S in CoP-Vp-LiPSs is greater than that of CoP-LiPSs, proving that the electrochemical transformation of LiPSs on the CoP-Vp surface is more favorable. Similar to anion vacancies, cation vacancies are extremely latent in regulating the electronic properties of the main material of Li-S batteries, thereby increasing the conductivity of the battery and the kinetics of redox reactions [280,281]. In addition, the cation vacancy can serve as a Li+ landing site to increase lithium storage performance and provide a higher charge storage capacity [282,283]. Zinc oxide (ZnO) samples containing zinc vacancies were synthesized by Mao et al. [284]. By testing samples containing different concentrations of zinc vacancies, the results show that zinc vacancy leads to diminished adsorption of polysulfide, it can improve the redox reaction dynamics and have high catalytic activity. Indeed, anionic defects and cationic defects are not usually present alone in the electrode material. Polarity materials such as transition metal chalcogenides (TMCs) have been used in Li-S batteries to improve sulfur electrochemistry. The introduction of anion/cation defects can synergistically restrain the shuttling effect of polysulfide and increase the conductivity, thus improving sulfur conversion dynamics. Luo et al. [285] synthesized disordered spinel nickel-cobalt oxide double-shelled (NCO-HS) with highly defective. For the scanning helium ion microscope (SHIM) test, the highly porous NCO-HS maintained structural integrity during helium ion bombardment without any damage or misalignment (Fig. 38(a) ). Furthermore, the defect sites in the NCO-HS can be clearly observed from the lattice stripes in the HRTEM images, as shown in Fig. 38(b). Fig. 38(c) intuitively illustrates the adsorption capacity of NCO-HS to LPS. The multiplier test in Fig. 38(d) shows the S@NCO-HS electrode with optimal multiplier performance, with a high discharge capacity of 855 mAh gâ1 at 5 C. The results indicate that anion/cation defects on NCO-HS can increase the conductivity of the sulfur electrode and alter the chemical interaction with polysulfides to achieve rapid reaction kinetics. The porous and hollow structure of NCO-HS provides sufficient reaction area and multidimensional channels for ion transport (Fig. 38(e)). The large internal gap in the hollow structure can promote sufficient sulfur load and buffer the volume changes during the reaction. The results of the constant potential intermittent titration (PITT) strongly proved that the S@NCO-HS composite ensures sufficient ion supply and rapid sulfur electrochemical reaction. 7.2.3 Lattice distortion The slow dynamics and shuttle effects of Li-S batteries severely limit its development in real life due to sulfur and Li2S insulation and deposition of soluble LiPSs at the cathode [286]. Hence, it is crucial to explore advanced catalytic materials to adjust the interfacial reaction kinetics and delay the LiPSs shuttling effect. Transition metal materials are widely used in Li-S batteries because they can accelerate the redox kinetics of sulfur materials. However, the transition metal material still has the problem of electronic insulation performance or poor electrical conductivity [287,288]. To solve the above problems, the researchers proposed to combine the transition metal catalyst with the highly conductive carbon material, to achieve favorable electrical conductivity and efficient catalytic activity. Recently, various metal nanoparticles (NPs) with high electronic conductivity have been widely used in Li-S batteries to improve the utilization rate of sulfur. More importantly, these metals have an active site that undergoes chemical interactions with LiPSs and enhances electrochemical redox kinetics [289,290]. Moreover, when heteroatoms are doped into the substrate lattice, it may bring about lattice distortion and strong electron interaction [291]. It has been proved that the cooperation of two or more diverse metals has achieved satisfactory results in electrocatalysis. These Nickel-Iron intermetallic compounds (Ni3Fe) are prepared to trigger efficient redox reactions in LiPSs [292]. Strong electron interactions and lattice distortion occurring between Ni and Fe atoms can activate the inferior Ni phase into a catalytically active Ni3Fe phase, as shown in Figs. 39(e,f) . The HR-TEM image in Fig. 39(b) exhibits clear lattice stripes with a d-spacing of 0.21 nm, which can be put down to the (111) crystal plane of the Ni3Fe [293]. It is noted that the HR-TEM image appears the wavy lattice structure as shown in Fig. 39(c) [202]. Ni3Fe@NCNT in Fig. 39(g) shows the extremely high specific capacity and long cycle life, indicating that the defect structure is beneficial to improve the catalytic active site of Ni3Fe, promote Li-ion diffusion and inhibit the shuttling effect of Li-S batteries. Introduce defects into the catalyst can increase the catalytic active site of the material, thereby reducing the electron transfer energy barrier and enhancing electrophilic adsorption [294â296]. Currently, as a result of the complex reaction mechanism, it is hard to clearly testify the effect of the degree of defect on the adsorption and transformation effect of LiPSs. Li et al. [297] created Se vacancies as quantified by changing the synthesis conditions, and the vacancy will induce the formation of the base surface dislocation, thus forming a series of samples of WSe2âx with gradient selenium defects, which is to study the effect of the degree of defect on the cathode process of Li-S batteries. Fig. 40(a) shows the typical TEM images of WSe1.51/CNT. More importantly, based on the Inverse Fast Fourier Transformation (IFFT) of the selected region in Fig. 40(a), in addition to the observable atomic point defects (Se vacancies) shown in Fig. 40(b), a large number of lattice defects (edge dislocation) appear on the base of tungsten selenide (Fig. 40(c)), with strain fields when the atomic bonds are compressed or stretched. Unsurprisingly, S/WSe1.51/CNT showed the best cycle performance compared to other samples, the discharge capacity was maintained at 741.4 mAh gâ1 after 1000 cycles, and the 1000th cycle was still as high as 99.2%, as shown in Fig. 40(d). It shows that samples with a regulated number of defects have optimal adsorption and catalytic capacity for LiPSs. In addition, the WSe1.51 with a moderate number of defects has the lowest charge transfer impedance (Fig. 40(e)). These results demonstrate that the defects favor charge transfer during electrochemical processes, but with substantial dislocations and structural distortions, excessive defects may negatively affect the electron transport of the material [298,299]. Fig. 40(f) more clearly shows the effect of the integrated performance of WSe2âx . Evidently, the production of defects advances all three core parameters, while excessive defects bring about a decrease in comprehensive performance due to decreased catalytic capacity due to strong adsorption. 7.2.4 Heteroatom doping It is widely used to improve the recycling capacity and multiplier capacity of Li-S cells, since heteroatom doping can adjust the surface characteristics and electronic structure of carbon-based material electrocatalysts [300]. In the Li-S system, the heteroatom-doping carbon is not only highly conductive, but also can enhance the chemosorption with LiPSs. Heteroatom doping after pyrolysis or etching can induce the generation of defects, thus increasing the number of highly exposed active sites, leading to a rapid redox conversion of polysulfides [267,301]. Moreover, the defective structure impedes electrolyte penetration and suppresses the volume expansion during cycling [302,303]. The preparation of a porous tubular graphite carbon nitride (PTCN) with N defects was induced by etching, as the main sulfur material in Li-S batteries [304]. As shown in Fig. 41(g) , the synthesized PTCN presents a tubular structure and many hollow nanotubes evenly distributed on the surface. Porous hollow structures confer highly exposed active sites to PTCN, and nanotube tentacles can provide faster electron conduction for the sulfur redox reaction. According to the optimized configuration diagram and density of state (DOS) curve of Li2S6 on TCN and PTCN, the nitrogen defects in PTCN have high activity and can promote the electrical conductivity of the material, providing more active sites for the redox reaction of sulfur. Moreover, the transition state of Li2S2 decomposition showed a lower Li2S2 decomposition energy barrier (0.59 eV) for PTCN than for TCN (1.07 eV), proving that nitrogen defects accelerate the LiPS conversion rate (Figs. 41(c,f)). Thus, the nitrogen defect in PTCN significantly increased the adsorption capacity and catalytic conversion rate of LiPSs. In the XPS spectra of N 1s, the three peaks can be attributed to pyridine N (398.8 eV), pyrrole N (400.3 eV), and graphite N (401.3 eV), respectively (Fig. 41(h)). The rich NC heteroatomic structure leads to the strong adsorption of the polar surface to the LiPSs by leading to a redistribution of electrons on the planar lattice. The PTCN/S electrode exhibited a narrower voltage difference and a higher current density than the TCN/S (Fig. 41(i)). Fig. 41(j) shows the cyclic performance of the PTCN/S and TCN/S electrodes at 0.2 C. The battery with a PTCN/S positive electrode can achieve a reversible specific capacity of 941 mAh gâ1 after 100 cycles, which is much higher than the TCN/S electrode battery. The EIS diagram shows that the PTCN symmetric battery exhibits a lower electron transmission resistance than the TCN, revealing the enhanced conductivity of the PTCN electrode (Fig. 41(k)). Furthermore, the lower start potential of PTCN in the LSV curve suggests a strong influence of PTCN on reducing the energetic barrier to the oxidative transformation of Li2S (Fig. 41(l)). Therefore, the rational design of the defects not only significantly improves the electronic conductivity, but also effectively anchors and catalyzes the polysulfide conversion. Even though the country pays more and more attention to âclear water and green mountainsâ, the number of pyrolysis residues waste plastics (PRWP) has steadily increased, which causes the pollution of the soil, oceans, and ecosystems. So far, some âcleanâ waste plastic has been used as carbon sources, and PRWP has been used in research on Li-S batteries [305]. The author used PRWP as raw material to prepare N-doped carbon with graded porosity for Li-S batteries. With KOH annealing and subsequent ammonia thermal treatment, the residue has a graded porosity of 30% of the total pore volume (Fig. 42(a) ). According to the pore size distribution seen in Fig. 42(b), N-SPC increases the mesopore, especially in the range of 2â4 nm. Fig. 42(c) compares the static adsorption test results of the samples, and the adsorption capacity of N-SPC is significantly stronger than that of SPC. The Nyquist plot of the EIS plot shows that N defects increases at the cost of carbon, and N-SPC decreases R ct more than CB. As shown in Fig. 42(c), N-SPC shows an excellent rate capability at different current densities. Since sulfur is retained on the micropore and entered by lithium ions through the medium pore, the active material of N-SPC is well utilized. This study not only demonstrates that N doping-induced defects help to delay the decay rate of the discharge capacity, but also provides a precedent for the practical green design of waste plastic residues as carbon sources. 7.3 Li-O2 battery With high theoretical energy density (3500 Wh kgâ1) and environment-friendly properties, non-proton Li-O2 batteries are recognized as a technology that can surpass Li-ion batteries [306]. A typical Li-O2 battery mainly consists of three parts: porous O2 diffusion positive electrode, metal Li cathode, and organic Li+ conductive electrolyte. The Li-O2 battery works as follows: 2Li+ + O2 + 2eâ â Li2O2 (2.96 V), involving the ORR and the OER process [307]. While the reaction may seem simple, the actual process is quite complicated. The structure and form of Li2O2 have an extremely important impact on the charge and discharge capacity and overpotential of the battery, and Li2O2 and active intermediates can lead to the occurrence of side reactions to degrade electrode materials and electrolytes, thus reducing the coulombic efficiency and cycle performance of Li-O2 batteries [308,309]. Moreover, the dendrite produced by the Li metal anode and irreversible volume changes further reduce the life of Li-O2 batteries [310]. These problems prevent Li-O2 batteries to be further used in real life. Currently, the development of efficient catalysts with a specific geometry and modulated electronic characteristics is one of the most effective strategies to improve the performance of Li-O2 batteries. Defect engineering (intrinsic defects, vacancies, lattice distortion and atomic doping) exhibits great potential in adjusting the electronic distribution of the material, hence improving the electrochemical properties of the electrocatalysts [74,311,312]. Furthermore, the defects provide a rich available space for the deposition of the discharge products and provide a high density of reaction sites for the Li-O2 reactions [313]. The presence of defects can significantly improve the conductivity of lithium and promote charge transmission through Li2O2, thus improving the cycle stability of Li-O2 batteries [314]. 7.3.1 Intrinsic defects Carbon-based materials, due to their high electrical conductivity and easily adjustable electronic structures, are widely used in Li-O2 battery systems. Wang et al. [315] have synthesized Ti3C2 quantum dot clusters (Ti3C2 QDC/NC) loaded with rich edge defects and crystal boundary on N-doped carbon nanosheets (NC), showing excellent bifunctional catalytic activity and cycle stability. The HAADF-STEM image of Ti3C2 QDC/NC is displayed in Fig. 43(a) , and Ti3C2 QDC catalysts contain diverse defects of crystal boundary and edge defects, which may act as centers for redox reactivity, and optimize the electronic structure. As shown in the EPR map of Fig. 43(b), it can be observed that the adsorption peaks of Ti3C2 QDC/NC at g = 2.003 are significantly stronger than Ti3C2 SQD/NC and Ti3C2 MNS/NC. This implies that the defect site can attract the surrounding unpaired electrons. XAS shows that the defect triggers charge delocalization around the active site to control the valence state and electronic structure of the Ti3C2 QDC/NC (Fig. 43(c)). In addition, in the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curve (Fig. 43(e)), Ti3C2 QDC/NC shows more positive ORR and more negative OER start potential, implying better redox kinetics. As shown in Fig. 43(f), the Ti3C2 QDC/NC electrode exhibits a higher discharge/recharging capability of 16022/15026 mAh gâ1 at 200 mA gâ1 with coulombic efficiency of 93.8%, and shows excellent ORR/OER reversibility. The discharged Li2O2 products were characterized by SEM. As shown in Fig. 43(d), the Ti3C2 QDC/NC surface is uniformly covered with a large number of floral Li2O2 structures composed of smaller-sized thin nanosheets. The layered porous Li2O2 structure not only provides sufficient contact area to exploit the defect-regulated catalytic activity, but also increases the rate of charge transfer. As demonstrated by the calculated charge difference of Ti3C2 QDC in Fig. 43(g), significant electron rearrangements could be found at the crystal boundary and edge positions. Low coordination Ti and C atoms act as anode and cathode charge centers, respectively, favoring the effective charge transfer between the intermediate and the active site during the ORR. As shown in Figs. 43(h,i), the Ti3C2 QDC catalyst with exposed defect centers obviously reduced the reaction barrier and eventually yielded a total overpotential of ORR (0.15 V) and OER (0.37 V) with a total overpotential (0.52 V). By comparison, the voltage gaps for MNS and Ti3C2 SQD were 1.09 and 0.86 V, respectively. Theoretical and experimental results show that crystal defects as the catalytic active site could spontaneously change the local charge distribution, regulate the intermediate adsorption capacity and reduce the redox energy barrier during Li2O2 formation and decomposition, and synergistically enhance the electrocatalytic kinetics. It is well known that defect sites on carbon materials may be used as reaction sites for electrocatalysts. Transition metals (e.g. Pd, Ru) loaded on carbon defects can effectively alleviate side reactions and further improve stability [316]. Lu et al. [317] coated Pd nanoparticles on carbon defects by wet dipping chemistry, which largely inhibited the occurrence of the side reactions. Meanwhile, the Pd film is used as an electrocatalyst to give the OER an extremely low overpotential. As can be seen from the HRTEM image, the Pd film coating is discontinuous and exactly matches the (200) lattice plane of the metal Pd (Fig. 44(a) ). Fig. 44(b) shows the charge-discharge cycle curve at a current density of 50 Î¼A cmâ2. The charging potential (3.2 V) of the Pd/carbon sample is significantly lower than the original carbon cathode (4.2 V), suggesting that the coated Pd film can serve as an outstanding OER catalyst to boost the decomposition of Li2O2. As shown in Figs. 44(c,d), the C=O peaks disappeared and CâO peaks weaken after Pd coating, which indicates that the Pd is indeed coated on the carbon defects. Differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) measurements (Figs. 44(e,f)) indicate that a stable oxygen signal could be observed during charging, consistent with the theoretical two-electron transfer reaction (dashed line). It shows that the use of a Pd coating suppresses byproduct formation and reduces the overpotential. As shown in Fig. 44(f), the DEMS test performed after 10 cycles, only saw O2 with no other gas such as CO2, illustrating that fewer side reactions occurred during the 10th charge, improving the cycle stability of the Pd/carbon cathode. 7.3.2 Anion/cation vacancy Metal oxides are considered excellent electrocatalysts to heighten the electrochemical performance of Li-O2 batteries. Due to the weak interaction between fully oxidized metal oxides and stable O2 molecules, defect engineering improves the catalytic activity of Li-O2 batteries by fine-tuning the surface electronic structure of the material [318]. The introduction of oxygen vacancies can produce more electrochemical active sites while reducing the adsorption energy of the reaction, thus significantly improving the electrocatalytic performance. Co3O4 has excellent catalytic properties and high corrosion stability, which is one of the best candidates for oxygen electrocatalysts. The oxidation state of Co in Co3O4 lies between Co2+ and Co3+, not only generating reversible surface ion exchange of oxygen ions but also providing opportunities for electrons to interact with other oxides. Especially in the process of OER, it is important to improve the reversible stability and cycle life of Li-O2 batteries. Zhang et al. [319] synthesized rich-oxygen vacancy R-Co3O4 HPNS by wet reduction and calcination strategies, which consists of a large number of nanoparticles exhibiting a unique porous hollow structure. Compared with the original Co3O4 HPNS, introducing oxygen vacancy defective R-Co3O4 HPNS can produce more electrochemical active sites, improve the conductivity and accelerate the adsorption of oxygen molecules, thus boosting the performance of Li-O2 cells. Accordingly, R-Co3O4 HPNS exhibits reduced overpotential, higher discharge capacity, longer circularity, and improved multiplier performance. The introduction of the transition metal oxide RuO2 may heighten the oxygen vacancy concentration of Co3O4. Meanwhile, due to the synergy between Co3O4 and RuO2, it accelerates the charge transfer and regulates the electronic structure, thereby improving the activity against Li-O2. Zhang et al. [320] prepared RuO2-Co3O4 nanohybrids with rich oxygen vacancies and large specific surface area that can be used as catalysts in Li-O2 cells. The HRTEM images of the samples show 0.233 and 0.255 nm lattice stripes, indicating that RuO2 was introduced into Co3O4 (Fig. 45(a) ). In the O 1s spectrum (Fig. 45(c)), the peak at 531.2 eV represents the presence of the oxygen vacancy (O2) in the RuO2-Co3O4 nanohybrid. Wavelet transform (WT) analysis of Co K-edge EXAFS oscillations demonstrates that Co contains a lot of sites in low coordination, which introduces RuO2 into Co3O4 to expose more active sites and leads to increased electrocatalytic properties. At a current density of 200 mA gâ1, the RuO2-Co3O4 nanohybrid provides a high specific discharge capacity of 19747 mAh gâ1, higher than the Co3O4 (7070 mAh gâ1) (Fig. 45(d)). The cycling performance of the Li-O2 batteries with the RuO2-Co3O4 nanoscale mixture is significantly improved, and can be stable for more than 100 times (Figs. 45(e,f)). The calculated reaction free energy maps of RuO2-Co3O4 and Co3O4 are shown in Figs. 45(g,h), and the total overpotential of RuO2-Co3O4 (1.44 V) was significantly lower than Co3O4 (2.50 V). Excitingly, RuO2-Co3O4 exhibited better OER and ORR catalytic properties than Co3O4. In addition, Dou et al. [321] have synthesized an amorphous RuO2 nanoparticle-decorated carbon nanotube (A-RuO2@CNT) composite as an effective catalyst for Li-O2 cells. The amorphous catalyst has abundant oxygen vacancies and distorted atomic arrangements, providing sufficient active sites for the reaction and enhancing the adsorption of Li-O2 intermediates. Bimetallic oxides with various metal combinations of different valence states can offer synergistic catalytic activity through defect engineering [322,323]. Dai et al. [324] have synthesized a hollow sea urchin-like carbonate Ag2Mn8O16 electrocatalyst. Different valences (Mn3+ and Mn4+) and oxygen vacancies provide abundant active sites and the AgâMnâO bond accelerates charge conversion, together enhancing catalytic capacity. The graded porous Ag2Mn8O16 catalyst shows excellent electrochemical properties in Li-O2 batteries, including ultra-high specific capacity (7912 mAh gc â1 at 100 mA gc â1), preeminent rate capacity (5076 mAh gc â1 at 250 mA gc â1, 64.16%), and long-term cycle stability (133 cycles at 200 mA gc â1 within a limited capacity of 500 mAh gc â1). In addition, bimetallic nickel-cobalt oxide (NiCo2O4) is also a great potential bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst with sufficient catalytic active sites due to its two redox pairs (Co3+/Co2+ and Ni2+/Ni3+) [325]. Song et al. [326] prepared honeycomb NiCo2O4 nanosheets directly grown on a carbon cloth and showed excellent OER/ORR performance. The NiCo2O4 nanosheets provide sufficient space for the storage of Li2O2, while the midsole accelerates the diffusion rate of O2. Moreover, benefiting from the synergistic action of the Ni and Co redox electric pairs and oxygen defects, the Li-O2 batteries have desirable cycle durability and high discharge/recharging capacity. The Li-O2 battery using the NiCo2O4/CC as cathode exhibited admirable specific discharge capacities of 8388 mAh gâ1 (at 200 mA gâ1) and 5238 mAh gâ1 (at 400 mA gâ1), and provided a long-term cycle of 102 cycles. Indeed, a large number of studies have demonstrated that oxygen vacancies in a transition metal oxide can facilitate electron transfer, thereby reducing the overpotential and enhancing the electrochemical properties. Li et al. [327] used the spinel NiCo2O4 (NCO) as a model to form oxygen vacancies and regulate its concentration by controlling the time of the magnetron sputter. In addition, the relationship between oxygen vacancy concentration and the catalytic activity of Li-O2 cells was comprehensively investigated by using experimental and DFT calculations. The XRD pattern exhibits a typical spinel structure, proving that the magnetron sputtering does not break the crystal structure or form a new phase in a specific time range (Fig. 46(a) ). Besides, with increasing sputtering time, the sharp diffraction peaks gradually widened and the intensity gently diminished, suggesting that energetic particle bombardment produces defects and lattice distortion. From the transient PL spectra, the concentration of oxygen vacancies increases as the time of magnetron sputtering increases, indicating that regulating the time of magnetron sputtering can adjust the oxygen vacancy concentration (Fig. 46(b)). The effect of oxygen vacancy on the electronic structure of the NCO surface and the nexus to catalytic activity was also investigated by DFT calculations. The rich electronic states can be observed near the Fermi level (E f) of the magnetron sputtering NCO, as shown in Fig. 46(c). The results are attributed to the increased E d energy attributed to the oxygen defects (Fig. 46(d)), causing an upward shift in the center of the d-band. Massive antibonding states appear nearby the Fermi level, which can facilitate electron transfer and heighten the carrier concentration. Excessive oxygen vacancy concentration not only destabilizes the crystal structure, but also affects the electron-absorbing capacity of NCO from Li2O2, suppressing subsequent decomposition, and then affects the OER catalytic activity of NCO. Fig. 46(f) exhibits the first discharge-charge curve of Li-O2 batteries with a cut-off capacity of 2500 mAh gâ1 at the current density of 500 mA gâ1. Unsurprisingly, the reduction peak of NCO 10 min is located in the most positive position, with an ultra-low overpotential (0.49 V), which shows excellent bifunctional catalytic activity. Furthermore, cells with NCO 10 min electrodes showed better cycling performance compared with cells with NCO 0, 5 and 15-min electrodes. The above experimental results demonstrate the importance of regulating defect concentrations. The electrode XRD diagram of different discharge/charging stages is shown in Figs. 46(g,h), the characteristic peak of Li2O2 only completely disappeared on the NCO 10 min electrode surface after the fifth charge, while the signal peak of Li2O2 can still be found on the surface of the other three electrodes. The results fully demonstrate the superior ability of NCO 10-min electrodes to reversibly catalyze the generation and decomposition of Li2O2. Thus, the introduction of oxygen vacancy not only regulates the electronic structure of the metal cation and stimulates the OER dynamics, but also moderate concentrations of oxygen vacancy provide the optimal adsorption force of oxygen, thereby facilitating the ORR dynamics. The transition metal oxide molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is considered a new catalyst for Li-O2 batteries, with excellent electrochemical properties. However, the active site of MoS2 is mainly distributed in the low-coordination unsaturated marginal region of laminar structures, the mainly highly exposed base atoms have yet to exert their unique structural advantages. Defect engineering in the surface regulation of MoS2 can heighten the intrinsic conductivity and increase the marginal active site of MoS2 to enhance the activity. Liu et al. [328] grew MoS2 nanosheets (MoS2âx ) containing sulfur vacancies in-situ on microporous carbon paper, which was used as the cathode of Li-O2 cells. The MoS2âx cathode containing S-defect showed excellent electrocatalytic performance with a total potential difference of 0.59 V and a discharge capacity of 8851 mAh gâ1. The S defects can play a part as an electron donor and achieve charge redistribution to improve the intrinsic conductivity of MoS2. Notably, the S-defect can be exposed to the active site on the basal surface, exhibiting excellent electrocatalytic activity [329]. It is well known that carbon materials as a matrix can significantly enhance the conductivity of electrocatalysts. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have become an ideal material for Li-O2 batteries because of their strong adsorption force, low cost, and large specific surface area. However, CNTs will react with electrolytes and even produce discharge products at high potential, leading to the generation and accumulation of by-products and the degradation of battery performance [330]. Li et al. [331] synthesized 2H-MoS2 nanosheets with large S vacancies, and the S vacancies and nanosheet structures together improve the electrocatalytic activity of the Li-O2 batteries cathode catalyst. As shown in the HRTEM diagram in Fig. 47(a) , the 2H-MoS2 nanosheet clearly shows the nuclear shell structure that contains the MoS2 sheet. Defective areas consisted of disordered and lacking crystal surfaces are shown in yellow circles. The STEM results show that sulfur vacancies are distributed at random on their surface, expressed as a yellow cycle, which can act as an active site and contribute to the improvement of electrocatalytic performance. It is well known that the intensity ratio of the D and G bands (I D/I G) reflects the degree of disorder of the carbon structure. Fig. 47(c) shows many defects in the carbon skeleton. Based on previous reports, the ratio of E1 2g/A1g represents the degree of edge exposure of MoS2, with the more edge exposure, the smaller ratio. As shown in Fig. 47(c), the coordination unsaturated edge site generated by the sulfur vacancy in MoS2âx @Cleadslead to its lower value of E1 2g/A1g than MoS2@CNTs. In the CV plot, the MoS2âx @CNT cathode exhibits a higher anode/cathode current and a larger area, indicating that the S-vacancy-rich MoS2âx @CNTs can greatly promote the generation and decomposition of discharge products (Fig. 47(d)). As shown in Fig. 47(d), the formation and decomposition of Li2O2 in the MoS2âx @CNT cathode areas are highly reversible. Even after 150 cycles at 200 mA gâ1, it can still be observed that no other by-products were engendered, suggesting that it can serve as an effective bifunctional catalyst for ORR and OER in Li-O2 batteries. Compared with MoS2 nanosheets, the MoS2 quantum dot has a strong quantum size effect and more edge defects, which is a Li-O2 battery electrocatalyst with great potential [332]. Sun et al. [333] prepared MoS2 quantum dots enriched in S vacancies to expose the marginal Mo active site and enhance the activity of ORR and OER. It is proved that the edge-rich S-vacancy MoS2 quantum dot makes the cathode surface form an amorphous Li2O2 film, which is beneficial to promote the generation and decomposition of Li2O2. Importantly, the rich-edge S-vacancy MoS2 quantum dot can run over 230 cycles at a high current density, which is almost nine times more stable than the massive MoS2. According to the DFT calculations, the rich-edge S-vacancy MoS2 quantum dots can effectively reduce the overpotential between the ORR and the OER. This is the first demonstration from experiments and theory that the edge-rich S-vacancy MoS2 quantum dots have excellent ORR and OER catalytic properties. In addition, the ternary sulfide (AB2S4) receives increasing attention for its unique surface electronic properties. Among them, ZnIn2S4 has become an emerging catalyst candidate owing to its excellent chemical stability and abundant active site for the adsorption and activation of O2. The introduction of defects can adjust the electronic structure and heighten electron transmission, thereby improving the catalytic activity of materials [334]. Surface sulfur defects could modulate the electronic structure to expose massive unsaturated sites, and generate strong interactions at the interface, promoting effective electron delocalization and activating the reaction site [335]. Liang et al. [336] synthesized Ru/ZnIn2S4 (Ru-ZIS-Vs) Mott Schottky heterojunction with surface sulfur vacancy (VS) modification. The TEM diagram clearly shows the presence of an S vacancy (Fig. 48(a) ), and the doping of Ru can deform and blur the lattice, forming a rough surface. Besides, the S 2p 3/2 and S 2p 1/2 peaks of ZIS-Vs positively shifted 0.13 and 0.15 eV compared to ZIS and Ru-ZIS-Vs, respectively (Fig. 48(b)). The presence of sulfur vacancy causes the decrease of electron density on S, and the nuclei of S elements reinforce the attraction to the extranuclear electrons, thereby facilitating a positive shift in the binding energy, while Ru doping can compensate for the lacking extranuclear electrons of S. Then, PL spectroscopy tests showed (Fig. 48(c)) that the presence of Vs extremely shortens the electron transfer path, which facilitates the fast electron transfer [337]. While the introduction of Ru nanoparticles bridges Vs more from the interfacial gap of the ZIS rather than fully fills Vs, which favors the fast charge transfer process [338]. Furthermore, the band maps of ZIS, ZIS-Vs, and Ru-ZIS-Vs are shown in Fig. 48(d). The induced sulfur vacancy and Mott-Schottky interface formed after Ru doping can change the valence and conduction band values of ZIS, thus greatly promoting the charge transfer rate and enhancing the catalytic activity. The first charging/discharging curve is shown in Fig. 48(e), where the discharge and charge capacities of Ru-ZIS-Vs electrodes at a current density of 500 mA gâ1 are 3532 and 3316 mAh gâ1, respectively, much higher than ZIS-Vs and ZIS electrodes. As can be seen from the CV diagram, the Ru-ZIS-Vs electrodes not only exhibit a high peak current, but also have low starting potentials for the ORR and OER (Fig. 48(f)). The results suggest that sulfur vacancies can provide rich surface-active sites for O2 activation and adsorption, thus improving the catalytic properties of ORR and OER. Fig. 48(g) shows the cycling performance of Li-O2 for cells with a cut-off capacity of 1000 mAh gâ1 at a current density of 100 mA gâ1. The ZIS-Vs and ZIS electrodes operate stably for less than half the time of the Ru-ZIS-Vs electrode (1284 h). The XPS results of different stage electrodes were analyzed and the C 1s peak evolution demonstrated a highly reversible charge and discharge process on Ru-ZIS-Vs with no residual by-products (Fig. 48(h)). Except for the oxygen and sulfur vacancies, the Se vacancy serves as a typical anion vacancy. The introduction of Se vacancy is beneficial to improve the carrier concentration and adjust the surface adsorption energy of oxides, thus improving the catalytic activity and conductivity of metal selenide and expediting the charge transfer during OER and ORR [339,340]. Most importantly, the introduction of Se vacancies tends to form disordered structures, which would often favor a redistribution of the local electron density, increase the density of states nearby the Fermi level, and make them highly active sites [341]. Hou et al. [342] synthesized NiSe-vacancy-rich Se nanorods (V Se-NiSe@NF) loaded on the Ni foam frame. Se atoms were removed from the NiSe lattice by Ar plasma etching to stimulate the generation of Se vacancies. V Se-NiSe@NF-based Li-O2 batteries not only have a low overpotential, but also significantly improve the cycle life (over 950 h). In brief, the porous framework with rich defects provides sufficient catalytic sites for ORR/OER to effectively facilitate the redox reaction dynamics and can improve electron conductivity for rapid electron transport. Furthermore, the authors investigated the role of Se vacancies in integrated electrodes composed of CoSe2 nanowires anchored to the N-CC skeleton [343]. Fig. 49(a) intuitively shows the formation mechanism of the Se vacancy. The elastic collision of Ar and Se ions brings Se ions from the initial lattice while retaining the electrons and creating large vacancies on the surface of CoSe2. The introduction of Se vacancies in the c-CoSe2 lattice can efficaciously adjust the electron density near the Fermi level and stimulate molecular orbital hybridization, thus creating more unsaturated coordination sites and suspended bonds to promote the intrinsic activity of CoSe2. The presence of the Se vacancies is clearly visible from both the TEM and the HRTEM (Fig. 49(b)). Figs. 49(c,d) shows the performance of Li-O2 batteries using V Se-CoSe2@N-CC as the cathode with a low 0.81 V overpotential and high coulombic efficiency (99%), up to a specific capacity of 6089 mAh gâ1, and increased cycle stability (> 955 h). The excellent electrochemical properties are mainly attributed to two points. Firstly, the Se vacancy provides a plenitudinous active site and enhanced storage space for the discharge products. Secondly, Se vacancy regulates the electronic structure and accelerates the deposition/decomposition of discharge products, significantly heightening the catalytic activity of ORR, thus effectively improving the cycle life. In Fig. 49(e), no characteristic peaks of Li2O2 and Li2CO3 were seen on the surface of the V Se-CoSe2@N-C-C electrode, which proves that the introduction of Se vacancy endows the V Se-CoSe2@N-CC electrode with excellent bifunctional catalytic activity, efficaciously promoting the reversible generation/decomposition of Li2O2 and hindering the occurrence of parasitic reactions. In addition to anion vacancies, cation vacancies are also gradually applied in Li-O2 batteries. Cation vacancies can adjust the atomic structure and electronic properties of the material surface to facilitate charge transfer and redox reaction kinetics [135]. Among transition metal oxides, perovskite oxides are considered one of the most potential bifunctional electrocatalysts for oxygen electrode reaction due to their high ionic and electronic conductivity, high chemical stability and adjustable electronic states [344]. The introduction of an A-site cation vacancy can generate appropriate eg orbital filling values, accelerating the ORR and OER dynamics in Li-O2 cells. For example, Du et al. [345] synthesized La0.7MnO3âÎ´ (L0.7MO) with A-site cation vacancies, whose large specific surface area and magnanimous La vacancies significantly improved the kinetics of OER in Li-O2 cells. The L0.7MO-based Li-O2 battery provides low voltage clearance (0.38 V), excellent discharge capacity (29286 mAh gâ1) and long cycle stability (375 cycles under 300 mA gâ1).
