The results proved that the introduction of La vacancies can significantly regulate the electronic structure of L0.7MO, increase the active site for the OER, and provide sufficient storage space for Li2O2. Moreover, the existence of the La defect also enhances the hybridization between the Mn 3d and O 2p states, regulates the filling state of the eg orbit in the active Mn cation, and improves the conductivity of the L0.7MO catalyst. Thus, L0.7MO exhibits excellent bifunctional electrocatalytic activity against the ORR process in the Li-O2 battery. Although oxygen vacancies are a common anion vacancy in cobalt oxides, researchers will focus more and more attention on cobalt cation vacancies. Cation vacancies can regulate the charge redistribution on the cobalt oxide surface and change the electronic state, thus significantly improving the electrochemical properties. Liu et al. [346] prepared cobalt oxide (Co3âx O4) with cation vacancies by hydrothermal and calcination method. The cationic cobalt vacancy in the red circle can be observed in Fig. 50(a) , and the recorded intensity distribution of the corresponding region shows the presence and arrangement of cobalt atoms (Fig. 50(b)). The EPR signal for all the samples is at g = 2.004, indicating the generation of cation vacancies in Fig. 50(c). With the increasing temperature, the vacancy concentration gradually decreases due to the atomic rearrangement. The inductively coupled plasma (ICP) test shows the presence of a cobalt vacancy (Fig. 50(d)). In Fig. 50(e), CV measurements were performed to further investigate the electrochemical properties of the different cathodes at a scanning rate of 0.1 mV sâ1. The Co-300 electrode has the largest current density and the largest curve area among all the positive electrodes, indicating that Co-300 possesses higher OER/ORR activity. In addition, the Co-300 cathode catalyst shows a high charge/discharge ratio (13254/14517 mAh gâ1) and an excellent coulombic efficiency (91.3%), and shows a minimum overpotential (0.23/1.15 V). The Co-300 electrode has excellent cycling performance (Fig. 50(g)), and the discharge product is almost completely decomposed after 70 cycles with good reversibility (Fig. 50(h)). The disappearance of the Li2O2 diffraction peak in the cathode XRD map after 70 cycles indicates the reversible formation and decomposition of Li2O2 in Co-300. The experimental results demonstrate the positive contribution of metal vacancies to the electrocatalytic properties of cobalt oxide and will provide ideas for the rational design of advanced materials with unique vacancies for promising applications. 7.3.3 Lattice distortion Besides the intrinsic defects and vacancies, lattice distortion is also one of the important strategies to improve the performance of ORR and OER of electrocatalysts. Lattice defects promote the exposure of the active site and optimize the surface energy of adsorbing aerobic intermediates, thus improving the electrochemical activity of oxygen reduction and discharge product decomposition in Li-O2 batteries [347]. Therefore, the rational preparation of catalytic materials with atomic precision defects is one of our research directions to improve the performance of Li-O2 batteries. N-doped lattice-defect-rich MoS2 (N-MoS2) catalysts were prepared by Cao et al. [348]. Li-O2 batteries with N-MoS2 catalyst as the cathode show a high initial specific capacity of 5500 mAh gâ1 at 100 mA gâ1, which has good reversibility and efficiency. The higher specific capacity of N-MoS2 is attributed to the abundant defects and porous structures, providing more active sites for electrocatalytic reactions, boosting the decomposition of discharge product and enhancing redox kinetics. Liang et al. [349] carefully designed the CoSe2@NiSe2 catalysts with different heterogeneous interfaces as the cathode material for Li-O2 batteries. The HR-TEM images (Figs. 51(a,b) ) and the corresponding FFT mode (illustrated in Figs. 51(a,b)) intuitively represent the lattice distortion caused by diverse degrees of the Jahn-Teller effect. Notably, in Fig. 51(b), the disordered atoms rearrange to form heterogenous interfaces causing changes in electron density at the interface, and the area with strong electron-donating ability is favorable for the ORR reaction, and the OER reaction is facile to be carried out in the electron-deficient area. The rearrangement of electron density increases the possibility that oxygen electrocatalytic reactions will occur [350]. In Fig. 51(c), CoSe2@NiSe2 shows admirable discharge/charge capacity (3530.1/3485.6 mAh gâ1), low overpotential (1.21 V) and excellent coulombic efficiency (98.7%). As shown in Fig. 51(d), the CoSe2@NiSe2 electrode exhibits more positive ORR onset potential and more negative OER onset potential, and the peak current density of the CoSe2@NiSe2 electrode is much higher compared to the other samples. In addition, the CoSe2@NiSe2 electrode showed outstanding cycling stability up to 1200 h (Fig. 51(e)). The exceedingly electrochemical properties of the CoSe2@NiSe2 electrodes are attributed to the active site that is greatly enriched by lattice defects. Second, the built-in electric field formed at the CoSe2@NiSe2 heterointerface generates charge redistribution, facilitating charge transfer to expedite the kinetics of the oxygen electrode reaction. Importantly, the reversible properties of the OER and ORR processes on the CoSe2@NiSe2 electrodes are superior, and the additional active sites brought by the atomic array distortion are very favorable for the formation and decomposition of the charge and discharge products. The TEM diagram of the different stages of the CoSe2@NiSe2 electrode shows no palpable residue of the products after the circulation, proving excellent ability to decompose the discharge products in Figs. 51(fâh). 7.3.4 Heteroatom doping At present, the high valence state doping of foreign atoms to adjust the electronic distribution and surface properties of materials has become one of the most efficient methods to promote the performance of the cathode electrocatalyst for Li-O2 batteries [351]. The heteroatom doping method is not only environmentally friendly but also mild and simple. For example, Li et al. [352] generated oxygen vacancies in Co3O4 by incorporation of cerium, not only promoting charge migration by delocalizing electrons by forming unsaturated coordination sites, but also acting as active sites to anchor O2 and Li2O2 thereby enhancing the dynamics of ORR and OER. Ce-Co3O4-based Li-O2 batteries have a low overpotential (0.9 V), a large specific capacity (8250 mAh gâ1) and a long cycle life, confirming the excellent bifunctional catalytic activity. The relationship between surface properties and catalytic activity established through defect engineering can be used as an innovative strategy, guiding the further development of high-performance electrode materials for Li-O2 batteries. Porous inorganic nanotubes are one of the common electrocatalysts. The rich-N-defect porous inorganic nanotubes (TiN NTs) can be prepared by using nitride (N3â) substitution of oxide (O2â), which shows high conductivity, a large number of crystal defects and an effective mass diffusion path [353]. Since the defect mixing structure can enhance the charge transfer at the interface, crystal vacancies are produced by notable changes in the formation enthalpy of the defect mixing structure. Jin et al. [354] synthesized porous TiN NT-LDH nanohybrids with controllable defect structures that significantly enhanced the electrocatalytic redox-active. In Fig. 52(a) , a growing LDH on a porous TiN NTs produces a tightly coupled TiN-LDH nanohybrid. The shortening of the TiâN bond was observed from Ti K-edge FT EXAFS data (Fig. 52(b)), implying an increasement in the lattice enthalpy of the defective TiN, which can offset the lattice energy loss caused by the formation of nitrogen vacancies. The structural changes after hybridization can stabilize the defective TiN structure, leading to the additional formation of crystal defects. As shown in Fig. 52(c), the nitrogen vacancies formed at the TiN-LDH interface appear to be more thermodynamically favorable than at TiN (001), offering strong theoretical support for hybridization-driven nitrogen vacancy formation. The results in Fig. 52(d) emphasize that the charge transfer near the interface. Furthermore, the EXAFS results provide strong evidence for the formation of charge transfer-driven defects in TiN NT, which contribute to a concomitant increase in lattice energy and entropy (Fig. 52(e)). For the LSV data as shown in Fig. 52(f), the TiN-LDH nanohybrids exhibited observably higher OER electrocatalytic activity, lower overelectric potential and higher current density compared to the original Ni-Fe-LDH and porous TiN NTs, emphasizing the significant advantages of tight hybridization with defective TiN. According to EIS analysis (Fig. 52(g)), TiN-LDH-2 showed the lowest charge transfer resistance (R ct), indicating that the hybridization of TiN NTs significantly enhances the LDH charge transfer kinetics. Li-O2 batteries with TiN-LDH-2 as the cathode show ultra-high capacity (4680 mAh gâ1) and low overpotential (1.65 V), indicating the beneficial effects of Li-O2 performance batteries. Fan et al. [355] introduced N atoms into MoS2 to prepare sulfur-enriched vacancy N-MoS2 to improve the ORR and OER kinetics of rechargeable Li-O2 cells. The signal observed by the EPR spectra at 3500 cmâ1 is attributed to the sulfur vacancy. The intensity of N-MoS2 is much higher than MoS2, attesting to more sulfur vacancies on N-MoS2. The introduction of N atoms replaces part of the sulfur atoms, creating more sulfur vacancies. It is beneficial to improve the adsorption kinetics of Li+ and O2 in Li-O2 cells. In Figs. 53(c,d) , the three-electrode system was used to compare the electrocatalytic activities of ORR and OER. Due to the formation of the Mo-N bond in MoS2, it is clear that N-MoS2 has a corrected half-wave potential (0.81 V) and a higher limit current density (â4.76 mA cmâ2) rather than MoS2, proving that the N-doping efficaciously advances the ORR catalytic reaction process. The OER potential of N-MoS2 (1.56 V) is much lower than the MoS2 at 10 mA cmâ2, indicating that the OER activity of N-MoS2 is improved. As a result of the strong electronegativity of N, electron-deficient Mo atoms prefer to form higher oxidation valence states, expediting the multi-electron transfer process in the OER to produce a highly active OER catalyst. Moreover, the gap between MoS2 nanosheets is opened during N doping, exposing more catalytic sites, which improves the catalytic properties of ORR and OER. In the CV curve of the Fig. 53(e) plot, N-MoS2 exhibits the lowest polarization voltage difference and the highest oxidation and reduction peak current density. The discharge ratio of the installed Li-O2 battery with N-MoS2 as the cathode electrocatalyst is 5205.5 mAh gâ1 at a current density of 100 mA gâ1, much higher than MoS2 (2600.3 mAh gâ1). In a word, the developed N-MoS2 can be deemed as a potential cathode catalyst for Li-O2 cells. 7.4 Other metal-based batteries Electrochemical energy storage technology is of great significance to alleviate the increasing threat of fossil energy scarcity and environmental pollution. In addition to the above Zn-air, Li-O2 and Li-S batteries, the power density and long-term durability of secondary energy storage systems such as Na/Al-O2, Li/Zn-CO2, and Na/K-S are also strictly limited by charge/mass transfer dynamics during ORR/OER, which will inevitably lead to reduced energy conversion efficiency and unsatisfactory cycle stability [356,357]. Therefore, high-efficiency catalysts are essential to accelerate the reaction kinetics in these secondary battery systems [358]. 7.4.1 Intrinsic defect Al-air batteries can directly convert Al into powerful power through the inexhaustible oxygen in the air, and are expected to serve as one of the energy carriers of the next generation, which has ideal working voltage, high theoretical capacity and energy density [357]. More importantly, Al is the most abundant resource in the earth's crust with low bulk procurement prices [359]. However, due to the slow self-corrosion of Al anode, Al-O2 batteries are still in laboratory-scale products. Liu et al. [360] prepared a 3D composite catalyst (CMO/CNTs/3D) composed of CoMn2O4 nanorods supported by nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes/graphene. CMO nanoparticles can induce more oxygen-containing functional groups and surface defects. The emerging weak d-band of CMO/CNTs/3D graphene exhibits significantly increased defects, resulting in more electrocatalytic active sites. The CMO/NCNTs/3D graphene hybrid catalyst showed significant ORR electrocatalytic properties under alkaline conditions, even outperforming the commercially available 20 wt% Pt/C catalyst. Furthermore, Al-O2 batteries with CMO/NCNTs/3D graphene as the cathode catalyst obtained an open circuit voltage of 1.55 V with a specific capacity of 312.8 mAh gâ1, superior to Al-O2 cells with NCNTs/3D graphene as the catalyst. Na-O2 batteries have been widely studied for their advantages of low cost, higher abundance over lithium, high capacity, and high energy density. EnterrÃ­a et al. [361] studied graphene aerogels with different porosity, and the optimized electrode showed a capacity of 6.61 mAh cmâ2. Defects are thermodynamically unstable high-energy sites that favor the nucleation and trapping of metal oxide particles. The 3D arrangement of GS in the aerogel cathode can expose a larger proportion of defects compared to thin films, which enhances diffusion channels for the Na+/O2 supply. As a result, the overpotential is as low as 250 mV and the efficiency exceeds 95% after 39 cycles (486 h) at 0.5 mAh cmâ2. By reducing the capacity cut-off value, the cycling ability is further increased to 745 h (128 cycles). Furthermore, Cheon et al. [362] prepared the graphene nanoshell/mesoporous carbon nanohybrid (GNS/MC) as an efficient and stable bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst for rechargeable aqueous Na-O2 batteries. GNS/MC has a highly graphitized, defect-rich nature, which contributes to the enhanced OER activity (overpotential of 340 mV to 10mA cmâ2) and the high stability of both OER (20 h at 5 mA cmâ2) and ORR (30000 times at 50 mV sâ1). GNS/MC showed high oxygen electrode activity (0.72 V), greatly outperforming the Ir/C (0.91 V) and Pt/C (1.01 V) catalysts. Moreover, in water-borne Na-O2 battery tests, GNS/MC air cathode-based batteries showed a lower voltage difference of 115 mV than Ir/C (364 mV) and Pt/C (179 mV) based batteries. Notably, the GNS/MC-based battery is the first example of a rechargeable waterborne Na-air battery. Among many secondary energy storage systems, Li-air batteries have the highest theoretical energy density (3500 Wh kgâ1). Nevertheless, there is 0.04% CO2 gas in the air, resulting in the inevitable byproduct production of lithium carbonate in the discharge process [363]. Compared with Li2O, Li2CO3 is more thermostable and more difficult to decompose [364]. The irreversible formation of Li2CO3 seriously affects the reversibility and cycle stability of metal-air batteries, which limits their practical application. Recently, metal-CO2 (metal = Li, Na, Zn) batteries have shown high energy and high-power density, especially using CO2 as an active material to generate electricity, which means that battery systems are expected to provide stable energy in the future [365]. The researchers found that Li-CO2 batteries with CO2 as the reaction gas have a high theoretical energy density (1876 Wh kgâ1) and have broad application prospects in energy storage and carbon dioxide recovery. Ye et al. [366] synthesized topological defect-based graphene (TDG) as a metal-free positive electrode of Li-CO2 cells, showing an unprecedented full discharge capacity of over 69000 mAh gâ1 at a current density of 0.5 A gâ1. Topological defects are introduced into the carbon skeleton to provide sufficient active sites for CO2 reduction (CO2RR) and oxidation (CO2ER) to facilitate the formation/decomposition of Li2CO3. DFT calculations reveal the superiority of negatively charged C atoms in topological defects as activation sites for CO2 molecule adsorption and Li2CO3 decomposition, and the heterocyclic pentagonal ring (C5) has a relatively low theoretical potential gap (1.01 V) during charging and discharging process. Therefore, the Li-CO2 battery of the TDG positive electrocatalyst exhibits a relatively small voltage gap of 1.87 V (Li/Li+) at 2.0 A gâ1 and an excellent long-term stable cycle life of up to 600 cycles at 1.0 A gâ1. Besides, defect engineering in carbon-based electrode materials plays an important role in activating the catalyst and improving the adsorption of Li-CO2 cell intermediates. Jin et al. [367] synthesized high-performance composite catalysts based on porous graphene-loaded carbon quantum dots (CQD/hG) by ÏâÏ stacking. The resulting CQD/hG composite catalyst has many edge defects around the pores of CQDs and hG, which act as catalytic active sites during the discharging and charging of Li-CO2 cells. The Li-CO2 battery achieves an overpotential as low as 1.02 V (Li/Li+) at a current density of 0.1 A gâ1, a discharge capacity of 12300 mAh gâ1 at a current density of 0.5 A gâ1, and excellent long-term stability (up to 235 cycles) even at high 1 A gâ1 current density. In addition to Li-CO2, combined with Zn dissolution/deposition reactions, CO2 electrochemical reduction reactions can be used in Zn-CO2 batteries for both CO2 conversion and energy output. Ni et al. [368] have carefully designed an inherent graphene-rich porous carbon embedded with single atom Fe-N4 sites (DNG-SAFe) in the presence of carbon-rich nitride (C-g-C3N4), demonstrating that the activity of intrinsic carbon defects can be significantly enhanced by coupling to single atom Fe-N4 sites. DNG-SAFe-based rechargeable Zn-CO2 batteries also exhibit considerable 86.5% CO selectivity at the discharge current density of 5 mA cmâ2 and excellent cycle stability. DFT calculations show that the intrinsic defect of Fe-N4 coupling reduces the energy barrier of CO2 RR and suppresses the hydrogen precipitation activity. 7.4.2 Anion/cation vacancy Metal oxides (such as MnO2) have outstanding advantages including high abundance, low cost and environmental friendliness. Jiang et al. [369] developed activity-enhanced MnO2 catalysts with rich oxygen vacancies and edges through the Ar plasma strategy to enhance the electrochemical properties of Al-air cells. A wealth of defects is triggered on the surface of the MnO2 nanowires, and the defect-designed MnO2 catalyst shows higher activity against the ORR (greater positive reduction potential and reduction current density). DFT calculations confirmed that the defect sites are favorable for oxygen adsorption and OâO bond activation. The resulting Al-air cells show higher voltage, greater power density and better durability. Similarly, Huo et al. [370] synthesized graded microspheres Î³-MnO2 nanorod assembly with large oxygen defects as an oxygen reduction electrocatalyst for Al-air cells. The introduced oxygen vacancy of Î³-MnO2 significantly enhanced the ORR electrocatalytic activity. As a result, using Î³-MnO2 as the cathode catalyst of Al-air cells can achieve an excellent power density of 318 mW cmâ2. In addition to Al-air cells, Wu et al. [371] successfully synthesized Ag-doped MnO2 nanowires using a simple hydrothermal method. The prepared Ag-doped MnO2 has significantly enhanced catalytic activity for ORR due to the surface lattice oxygen activation, increased conductivity of Î±-MnO2, and increased oxygen vacancy compared to the original oxygen. Furthermore, when the current density of the Mg-O2 cell is 134.5 mA cmâ2, the power density of the cell is 75.1 mW cmâ2. Zheng et al. [372] used NiO nanosheets with oxygen vacancies (NiO-Vo@CC) which are vertically grown on carbon cloth as catalysts for CO2RR and CO2ER in Li-CO2. The oxygen vacancies modified by the remaining electrons can not only act as electron-deficient carbon atoms on the surface of the electron donor (Lewis base), but also narrow the band gap of NiO. Thus, the optimized CO2 conversion kinetics can be obtained using the defective NiO-Vo@CC electrode. In addition to anion vacancies, the introduction of cation vacancies in metal oxides can significantly change the electronic structure of the material. For example, Xue et al. [373] prepared A-site cation defects (La1âx Sr x )0.98MnO3 catalyst by an improved solid-liquid method. A-site defects in perovskite materials can manipulate the valence state of the B position element to expose more active sites for the ORR, reduce oxygen migration energy and increase surface oxygen vacancies. Composites with 50% carbon and (La0.7Sr0.3)0.98MnO3 perovskite (50%LSM30) show the best ORR catalytic activity owing to its excellent oxygen adsorption capacity, and the durability of this catalyst is much higher than the commercial 20% Pt/C. In addition, the maximum power density of 50%LSM30 is 191.3 mW cmâ2 in the Al-air cells. It demonstrates that LSM/C composite catalysts with A-site defects can be used as promising ORR catalysts in metal-air cells. Kang et al. [374] prepared a Co-PBA (D-Co-PBA) with a defective [Fe(CN)6] vacancy as a cathode catalyst for a mixed Na-air battery. DFT calculations show that [Fe(CN)6] vacancies can effectively regulate the electronic structure of D-CoPBA, reducing the reaction barrier of the rate determination step towards the OER. In OER, the D-Co-PBA catalyst achieved a lower 400 mV overpotential at a current density of 10 mA cmâ2, outperforming Ir/C (430 mV) and Co-PBA (450 mV). The Na-air battery assembled by Pt/C and D-Co-PBA catalyst has a 1000 cycle discharge voltage of 0.15V, and a round-trip efficiency of 94.83%. Wang et al. [375] constructed a metal Bi with rich cation defects to regulate the electronic structure of the Bi site and enhance its intrinsic activity. The optimized samples showed higher selectivity for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction to formate (93.9% at 0.9 V) and greater current density (10 mA cmâ2 at 1.0 V), which are mainly attributed to the abundant defect sites and optimized electronic structure. The assembled Zn-CO2 cells showed a power density of 1.16 mW cmâ2 and cycle stability of up to 22 h. It highlights the role of the defect in the selective regulation of CO2 reduction. 7.4.3 Lattice distortion Mg-air batteries have attracted extensive research and attention due to their high energy density (3910 Wh kgâ1), rich resources, low cost and good safety. However, due to the slow dynamics and poor durability of the ORR, the actual Mg-air battery being used is well below the theoretical value [376]. As an alternative to commercial Pt/C catalysts, the highly active and abundant ORR electrocatalysts have great potential in improving the performance of magnesium air batteries. Among oxygen-reduction catalysts, transition metal oxides such as MnO2 attract much attention as ORR catalysts due to their considerable catalytic activity, environmental friendliness, and low cost. Modifying the surface electronic structure of the material by lattice modulation significantly improves the electrocatalytic properties. Zhou et al. [377] synthesized Cu-doped Î±-MnO2 (Cu-Î±-MnO2) nanowires. Based on XRD and XPS data, larger Cu2+ ions replacing Mn3+ (0.645 Ã) or Mn4+ (0.530 Ã) resulted in lattice expansion and an increased amount of Mn3+. The electrocatalytic results showed that Cu-Î±-MnO2 exhibited better ORR activity than the original Î±-MnO2 due to the reduced charge transfer resistance and the improved kinetic rate. In addition, Cu-Î±-MnO2 shows a maximum peak power density and high discharge voltage of 73.4 mW cmâ2 as a cathode catalyst for Mg-O2 battery. It provides an efficient and inexpensive method for improving electrocatalysts for Mg-air batteries. 7.4.4 Heteroatom doping The slow ORR dynamics on the cathode of Al-air batteries greatly limit their further development. Recently, heteroatom doping introduced edge deficient carbon materials has been certified to be one of the most promising ORR catalysts because it can regulate the charge redistribution of carbon atoms, enhance electron transport capacity, and act as an adsorption site for foreign ions, thereby increasing the electrode capacity [378]. Cheng et al. [379] synthesized oxygen and nitrogen co-doped carbon nanofibers (MnO/Mn2O3/ONCNF-n) by using oxygen plasma surface etching, as an effective electrocatalyst for ORR. The concentration of oxygen heteroatoms and vacancies in the carbon matrix is regulated by controlling the time of oxygen plasma etching. In addition, Al-air cells with the cathode MnO/Mn2O3/ONCNF-3 have a maximum power density of 129.7 mW cmâ2, showing comparable performance to that based on a commercially available Pt/C catalyst. Liu et al. [380] prepared high purity Co@CoO x /spiral nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes on carbon fiber paper (Co@CoO x /HNCNTs) and developed efficient and stable electrocatalysts and independent electrode structures for ORR to reduce the use of polymer binders in Al-air battery cathodes. The synthetic Co@CoO x /HNCNY-1h provides more abundant edge defects and active sites, and exhibits significant electrocatalytic properties against ORR in a basic medium. Furthermore, the Al-air battery using Co@CoO x /HNCNTs-1h as the adhesive-free positive electrode exhibited an open circuit voltage of 1.48 V and a specific capacity of 367.31 mAh gâ1 at a discharge current density of 1.0 mA cmâ2 with a maximum power density of 3.86 mW cmâ2. Wang et al. [381] employed a gas foaming strategy to create 3D layered porous N-doped carbon with high specific surface area and abundant biomass defects. Compared to Pt/C (0.856 V and 46.61 mA cmâ1), the obtained catalyst exhibited significant ORR characteristics, with a higher half-wave potential (0.861 V) and a slightly lower kinetic current density (32.44 mA cmâ2). In addition, when used as an air cathode catalyst, the Al-air battery has excellent discharge performance, with a power density of up to 401 mW cmâ2, an energy density of 2453.4 Wh kgâ1, and an extremely high open-circuit voltage of 1.85 V. In addition to Al-O2 cells, heteroatom doping is also widely used in other metal-O2 cells. Hu et al. [382] used S-doped graphene to avoid oxygen crossing to protect the potassium metal anode in K-O2 cells. The S and N-doped graphene led to higher defect densities, increasing the density of the reaction sites and facilitating a reversible KO2 formation-decomposition at the graphene cathode. Furthermore, K-O2 cells with S-doped graphene-protected anode and N-doped graphene cathode can provide a long life of over 550 h at 1000 mAh gâ1 with little by-product accumulation. Recent studies suggest that metal-free heteroatom doped carbon is expected as CO2RR and CO2ER dual functional catalysts for rechargeable Li-CO2 batteries. Li et al. [383] employ bamboo N-doped carbon nanotube fiber (B-NCNT) as a flexible and durable metal-free material, and prepared a flexible fiber Li-CO2 battery with super long cycle life, high multiplier capacity and large specific capacity. Profiting from the abundant pyridine group and abundant defects, the prepared Li-CO2 cells exhibit excellent electrochemical properties, a high full discharge capacity of 23328 mAh gâ1, a low potential gap of 1.96 V at a current density of 1000 mA gâ1, stability over 360 cycles, and good flexibility, which provides ideas for the research of Li-CO2 batteries in wearable electronic devices. Xu et al. [384] prepared a nitrogen-rich graphite carbon frame (Fe-Cu-C-N-C) with dense carbon nanotubes with Fe3+ and Cu2+, which serves as an advanced catalyst for Na-CO2 hybrid cells. As a cathode catalyst battery for hybrid Na-CO2, Fe-Cu-N-C can promote the rapid evolution and degradation of flocculent discharge products and achieve excellent long-term cycle performance of up to 1550 cycles (over 600 h), making it one of the best catalysts for hybrid Na in hitherto reported CO2/air cells. Excellent battery performance was attributed to the synergistic effects between the defect-rich interface, Fe/Fe3C nanocrystals, Fe-N x , and Cu-N x . In addition to metal-air batteries, defect engineering has also been widely used in improving the performance of M-S batteries in recent years. Room-temperature sodium-sulfur (RT Na-S) batteries offer broad prospects for the next generation of high-energy storage systems due to their high theoretical capacity and low cost of sodium and sulfur [385]. Mou et al. [386] prepared samples with a large specific surface area, rich micro/nanopore structures, and a nitrogen-self-doped nitrogen-doped porous carbon sheet (NPC). The introduction of porous structure and nitrogen self-doped graphite has the characteristics of obvious defect structure, and the obtained NPC sheet can significantly improve the spatial limitation of sulfur molecules, and effectively alleviate the dissolution of sodium polysulfide in the charge and discharge process of RT Na-S cells. Therefore, the optimal sample (S@NPC-700) is used as the cathode of the RT Na-S battery with a specific capacity of 280.9 mA hgâ1 at 2.0 C and maintains a reversible capacity of 418.9 mAh gâ1 at 0.5 C after 400 cycles. An S/N-doped 3D tubular pore porous carbon (MOF-C/S/PDAc) was prepared by Xiao et al. [387]. The Raman test of MOF-C/S/PDAc indicates that high-temperature vulcanization produces additional structural defects. As a result, the obtained composite material showed excellent electrochemical properties, with the compound electrode still reaching a high reversible capacity of 467 mAh gâ1 after 100 cycles of 0.1 A gâ1, along with excellent rate performance (201 mAh gâ1, 5.0 A gâ1). 8 Conclusions and outlook This review pays close attention to the recent research on defects in Zn-air, Li-O2 and Li-S batteries, including intrinsic defects, anion/cation vacancy defects, lattice distortion, heteroatom doping, etc. The defects can change the electronic structure and charge physicochemical properties, thus leading to fast ion diffusion and charge transfer, which makes them one of the ideal materials for energy storage. The introduction of defects in electrode materials can provide more storage and adsorption sites for external ions, producing a large number of active points, and contribute to accelerated electrode reaction kinetics and excellent metal-based battery performance. At the same time, the introduction of defects can also significantly enhance the stability and capacity of the battery. This review plans to emphasize the important impact of defect engineering in improving the performance of electrode materials and realizing the practical application of defects in metal-based batteries. However, there are still some concrete challenges about how to overcome the shortcomings in the application of defective electrodes as follows. There are still some problems that cannot be solved right now. For example, metal hydroxides, sulfide, and carbon materials are readily oxidized at the high operating potential of the OER, and the activity of the transition metal oxide catalysts in the oxidation environment are still unsatisfactory. Moreover, perovskite synthesis requires very high temperatures, and accompanying caking and agglomeration are often inevitable. (1) The improvement of synthesis methods can accurately generate and control the defective active sites of electrode catalytic materials. It is meaning a lot to employ a befitting sample analytical method and integrate the appropriate characterization methods to adequately expose more active sites and precisely control the synthetic location of defects on electrode materials. Moreover, it is important to explore effective ways to approach mass production and consistently high quality. The laboratory methods used do not meet the requirements, and it is urgent to explore new efficient and controllable large-scale synthesis methods. Large-scale production is not only limited by activity and stability, but also by the price and complexity of synthetic methods. The large-scale application of propulsion defect electrocatalysts is still the direction of our efforts. (2) Advanced characterization methods are demanded to monitor the change of defect concentration in the process of defect synthesis. It is necessary to regulate the suitable concentration of defects for the increasement of the initial coulombic efficiency and improve the stability of the battery, which is a vital factor to influence charge distribution and electrochemical performance in electrode materials. The characteristics and properties of the simulation system can be analyzed more deeply by combining precise calculation and experimental results. Not only the active sites can be explored, but also the degradation mechanism can be clearly revealed, which provides a solution to the activity and stability of metal-based batteries. Similarly, the DFT calculations are efficient to understand the relationship between defects and electrochemical properties, and electrochemical techniques are serviced to study the changing process of defective electrode materials during battery discharge. It is important to understand the surface chemical properties of electrocatalytic materials and understand the reaction mechanism. Moreover, exploring more accurate and advanced in situ characterization techniques is also essential and challenging. Currently, most of the characterization of the defects is static and can only provide information about the specific moment of the catalyst, which cannot accurately reflect the local coordination environment of the defects and the changes of the defect during the reaction process. Therefore, advanced in-situ characterization techniques should be developed to detect the defect evolution during electrocatalysis in real time which would be beneficial to reveal the actual role of the defects in the various electrocatalytic reactions. (3) The electrochemical mechanism of defects in metal-based batteries is deeply studied. For metal-based batteries, the understanding of the relationship between defects, electrochemical phase transition and performance is still in infancy. The bifunctional mechanism of ORR/OER depends on the relationship between the adsorption energy of oxygenated intermediates and the electronic structure of the catalyst. Although the volcanic framework is conducive to clarify this key concept, it is not sufficient to meet the requirements of current experiments. For example, the mechanism of continuous control of intermediates by single sites during discharge and charging is not clear, which is caused by defects. Although many recent works suggest that the presence of defects will improve the charge storage capacity and migration ability, and theoretical calculations show that better electronic conductivity and lower ion diffusion barrier, it is still necessary to measure more detailed structural and oxidation state changes through experiments to further associate defects during charge storage processes. In addition, the content of defects has a strong impact on the charge distribution and energy band structure of materials, so it is urgent to study the deep relationship between defect content and the electronic properties of materials. (4) Developing functionalized defect catalysts for achieving efficient and durable electrocatalysis. The current focus of the defective catalysts is on how to improve the activity of the electrocatalyst and the capacity of the battery. However, how to improve the stability of the defective electrocatalyst is still the bottleneck of the electrocatalyst. In addition, the defective electrocatalyst should be less stable under harsh reaction conditions such as strong acid and strong alkali environment or a high and low-temperature environment. Hence, developing defective electrocatalysts with high activity and stability remains extremely challenging. To sum up, the great effects on defects in electrocatalytic materials for the metal-based battery are methodically analyzed in this article. The enhancement of the performance for the metal-based batteries has made great progress through defect engineering. It is our conviction that defective electrode materials are useful in areas of electrochemical energy storage and conversion. Even with many difficulties, researchers are needed to accelerate the development of these technologies to achieve the goal of large-scale application of metal-based batteries in real life. Consequently, it is extremely expected that this review will present far-reaching enlightenment and inspiration for the design of sophisticated defective electrocatalytic materials and clearly propel the application of the battery territory in daily life. Colloid Interface Sci. 615 2022 527 542 Z. Wei, R. Wang, J. Colloid Interface Sci., 2022, 615, 527â542. Xiaobin Liu is currently a postdoctor at Qingdao University of Science and Technology. He received his PhD from the Institute for Advanced Materials and Technology at University of Science and Technology Beijing. His research interests focus on the synthesis of nanomaterials and their application in the field of electrochemical energy storage and conversion. Caixia Li received her B.S. degree in 2014 and her Ph.D. in 2019, both from Shandong University. Since August 2019, she joined in AIST-Kyoto University Chemical Energy Materials Open Innovation Laboratory (ChEM-OIL) as a postdoctoral research fellow (2019â2021). Now, she has joined the Qingdao University of Science and Technology as an associate professor. Her research is focused on the design and preparation of nano materials and their applications in the energy storage area. Lei Wang was awarded a PhD in chemistry from Jilin University in 2006 under the supervision of Prof. Shouhua Feng. He moved to Shandong University, The State Key Laboratory of Crystal Materials, as a Postdoctoral Scholar from 2008 to 2010. He is currently a professor of chemistry at Qingdao University of Science and Technology. His research interests mainly focus on the design and synthesis of functional organic-inorganic hybrids and porous MOFs materials, as well as their applications in photocatalysis, electrocatalysis, lithium-ion battery, etc.

coredata.dc:description: To conquer the instability of clean energy, developing high performance energy storage devices is of vital importance. Among them, metal-based battery (such as Metal-air batteries and metal-sulfur batteries) exhibited high potential for application due to their low lost and high energy density. The rational design of electrode materials (catalysts) plays an important role in improving the energy storage efficacy for metal based batteries and promoting the development of renewable energy technology. With the continuous development of energy storage technology and the in-depth exploration of the electrode reaction mechanism, the researchers found that the electrochemical performances of batteries can be significantly improved by modifying the electrode materials through defect engineering. The introduction of defects in the catalytic electrode material can not only adjust the electronic structure of the catalyst and enhance intrinsic activity, but also the defects can provide a large number of unsaturated sites and provide more favorable active centers for improving the electrochemical kinetics. This paper systematically reviews the action mechanism of defect engineering in the electrocatalytic process and the latest progress in energy storage developments. The reaction mechanism of metal-air batteries and metal-sulfur batteries is introduced firstly. Afterward, the types of defects (intrinsic defects, anion vacancy, cation vacancy, lattice distortion, and heteroatomic doping) and their preparation strategies are summarized. Subsequently, with the typical metal-based batteries (Zn-air battery, Li-O2 battery, Li-CO2 battery, Li-S battery, Na-S battery, etc.) as the foothold, the important role of defect engineering in its application is summarized in detail. Finally, the current challenges and development prospects of metal-based batteries are proposed, aiming to broaden the catalytic electrode materials through defect engineering and promote the commercialization process of clean energy storage devices.

coredata.dc:title: Defect engineering of electrocatalysts for metal-based battery
